description:
First time I ate here, I ordered take-out and the lomo saltado. The serving size was so small for what it was and I was a bit put-off. I came back and dined in (definitely a must to get the full experience!) and had a good time.  Loved the blue fries as complimentary appetizers. We shared the yucca fries, the cheese wontons, and the ceviche and were pretty full!  Would skip the yucca fries- i'm not a fan of how dense they are. The cheese wontons were good! I mean fried cheese- how can you go wrong there. The powdered sugar on the top was interesting and I wasn't a huge fan of the syrup, but liked that guac as a dipping. The ceviche was solid. Got the pisco sour. Tiny drink for the price! But still good.

Overall- a fun place to dine and have a nice dinner.
author: Vivian D.

description:
After shopping at Nordstrom, lovey and I decided to get dinner. We were craving Peruvian so I YELPED and found this place open on a Sunday. We arrived at 7 pm, so we just missed HH which was everyday. 
Anyway, I made reservations as we were driving there , so we were seated immediately even if we were early. 
So what did we have???
South of the border- mezcal drink with tamarind and pineapple
Sweet November - mezcal with pomegranate and rosemary 
Free taro chips with vinegar dip- so addicting , freshly fried 
Baby octopus
Scallops
Caramelized ribs with INKA cola
Pork shoulder with yucca
Rotisserie chicken with fries and salad

Everything was delish!! Flavors were on point from drinks to food. Loved every single bite of everything. We took home left overs chicken and pork. Again our eyes were hungrier than our tummies.  
Easy parking in Potrero. Good service and prompt. 
Will definitely be back. Trust!!!
author: Claudine V.

description:
I used to dine at the previous location. This was my first time at the new space. Here's a summary:

- service was good
- tables were sticky (our wine glasses kept getting stuck to the table)
- food was mediocre

I remembered the rotisserie chicken and ceviche tasting better. We also had the pork belly that lacked flavor. The scallops were the stand out dish. Our bottle of Malbec was really warm. 

Overall a decent meal but there are too many great places in the city for a return visit.
author: Yvonne N.

description:
BOMBBBB!!!! 

The menu is extensive, there's literally something for everyone! My friend has been here at least 4 times since he lives around the corner and he's had a different dish each time and has 

I ordered the short ribs with coconut rice and the flavors meshed well together while the short ribs were perfectly tender. My companion ordered the tuna and he thoroughly enjoyed his meal. 

I'm definitely looking forward to returning to Mochica!!
author: Danielle D.

description: Wow. I love this place. Super cute interior and the food is great. You get purple chips at the beginning and it is yummy. I got the aji de gallina was amazing. Some reviews on here said it was water down but I thought it was amazing. Every bite. The rotisserie chicken was yummy as well. The salad had a yummy dressing.
author: Tina L.

description:
I could not believe the one thing I wanted here was not available the "Leche de Tigre" cocktail. I could not leave here without trying something at least. My bartender/ waiter Maria recommend the fried calamari with a rocoto aioli mustard and lemon drizzled on top. It was pretty light, not overly fully, but just enough to hold me over until after work. 

Since the cocktail I wanted was not available Maria went ahead and charged my wine as the happy hour price. I thought that was nice, seeing how the main thing I wanted was unavailable due to insufficient ingredients. 

Next time I come back have to get a table. I felt a little uncomfortable for some odd reason. I understand it was busy at the time, but I was squished in the middle between two people like a can of sardines suffocating. I wasn't to sure if it was the recycled aluminum high chairs or if it was the lack of space. I would agree on both!
author: Elijajuan F.

description:
Delightful! Went with a girlfriend to catch up on a Saturday evening and ordered two tapas to share since we weren't that hungry. We waited outside for about 10 minutes before getting seated by a window. The service was on point, and the food was so fresh and delicious! 

The Cebiche Chino Pulpito (tuna ceviche) is a MUST! Refreshingly delicious with the plantain chips! And we also got the cream cheese filled wontons with an avocado dip, which was also a great fried dish to contrast the raw fish. 

Great place to catch up with friends, lively atmosphere with fun and delicious Peruvian tapas. Can't wait for my next Mochica visit.
author: Ylan T.

description:
This review is for their happy hour, but the service, food, and drinks were so good that we plan on coming back for their actual food! 

Why I was here // Came here looking for dinner on a Friday night around 5:30pm but to our dismay, they only take reservations for dinner on Friday and Saturday. Since we didn't have a reservation, we couldn't eat dinner there, however we were able to snag a seat at the bar for happy hour. 

Service // The bartender was superb! Super friendly, helpful in explaining and I was really happy with the Pisco Punch that he made for me. I usually dislike cocktails because they are too strong, but I was very happy with this cocktail! 

Bar Snacks // 
-ceviche cup (don't remember the full name) but it comes with chopped fish, shrimp, octopus and a very large mussel marinated in a tangy lemon juice. 
-Spareribs - these were delicious! Sauce is a bbq sauce made from Cola and the ribs were cooked to perfection and super meaty! 

Price // a bit on the pricier side, but for 2 drinks (cocktail, beer) and 2 side dishes, we paid about $48. 

Overall // I look forward to coming back here to try their other dishes!
author: Emily T.

description:
Mochica's was good but not over the top great. The only thing here that stood out was the churros. It was delicious!! Fresh, crunchy with a good springiness to the bite. The next thing that was good was the mixed ceviche dish that we got, I liked how there was a variety of things given. The pork belly fried rice, yucca balls, and BBQ ribs were decent. 

The churros dessert came with a small hot chocolate, so my friend decided to order another hot chocolate so we would both get one. They advertised it on their dessert menu was their special or famous hot chocolate. It was good, BUT it was not hot at all!.  Bummer deals! It really sucks when your hot chocolate comes out luke-warm. Despite that, decent food with lots of different items on the menu to choose from.
author: Cat T.

description:
Love this place!  Came here for dinner and was really pleased with our entire experience.  We had a reservation for 8:30pm.  When we arrived, our table was ready and we were seated right away. 

We were a bit overwhelmed by all the delicious menu options but our server, Daniel was super helpful.

We started with the traditional ceviche, then went to the ribs and finished with the pork belly and flan.

Each dish was really flavorful and unique.  The ceviche had really large pieces of fish and was very tasty. The ribs and the pork belly almost had a Chinese fusion feeling.  The flan was different, a bit of a citrus and quinoa?  

I'd highly recommend this restaurant to anyone in the area!
author: Kimberly L.

description:
Really cool spot we checked out for a dinner with a visiting coworker. The atmosphere is really hip, with high open ceilings and bright font and art plastering the walls in a busy but not overwhelming way. 

The food menu was mostly tapas style which meant I could try a bunch of things. And literally everything was awesome. The Mac & cheese was super creamy but with nice chewy pasta. The ceviche pesco was super fresh and had a great texture to the fish (red snapper). The chicken chicharrones were to DIE for and the service was so professional. 

Really pleased with my experience here and would happily come back and try some more things!
author: Quinn Li O.

description: I work two blocks away from Mochica Peruvian on weekdays, but I don't go here for lunch very often... because it's only open for lunch on Fridays.  But I've been here twice and was very pleased both times.   I've tried the chicken chinharron sandwich (with salsa criolla & rocoto aioli) and the crispy spareribs sandwich (cola bbq sauce, slaw, and huacatay aioli.  My friend Mike looooves the beef sandwich with tomato, onions and saltado sauce.  I tried a bite and like it too.  The fries that come with the sandwiches are great.  One time they weren't super hot but they were still tasty.  The atmosphere is lovely, I like the decor -- they probably have six different types of lighting fixtures in the main which make the place feel super quirky and fun.  The shelves of bottles over the bar are also fun; let's hope there's never an earthquake.  What?  In San Francisco?  Don't be ridiculous.
author: Dave M.

description:
It was ok.. I wanted to celebrate my birthday here so I had a reservation for a Sunday evening at 6:15 I believe. All my guests arrived late and I can tell the servers were getting annoyed but quite frankly I didn't care, I reserved, I was paying, so oh well.. 

I had the Aji de gallina, the food was alright, nothing to compare to a homemade dish.

 Mac n cheese was good but tasted too much like mustard. 

This is a good restaurant for someone that does not know the typical Peruvian flavors therefore will settle for mediocre food.

If you want some good Peruvian food go to El Porteño!! If you want some good Pollo a la brasa go to El Aji!!!!

And that's that
author: Nael M.

description:
I am Peruvian. I used to come to the original Mochica location And recommend it to friends. The chef at this new location must be new. The food is not great. The food is incredibly spicy, more than it should be. The anticuchos are inedible, the ceviche has too much rocoto, the lomo saltado has green onions??? The aji de gallina is watered down. Just a terrible food experience. 
The server was nice.
author: Ursula L.

description: Came in when they first opened. It was a slower night and we were seated in the left section of the restaurant. The servers were friendly, the food was quick to come out, but there was a fly that kept hovering around our table, which was an annoyance. The quality of the food was okay. We usually go to Fresca on Fillmore or La Mar on Embarcadero for Peruvian food, but we would give Mochica another shot. Portion sizes were enough to fill you up and the flavor profiles were on point. Not bland and not overly salty.
author: Aimee I.

description:
IMO one of the upcoming restaurant/bars with THE BEST PISCO SOURS you'll ever have.
First of all call and ask how long the wait is for seating. They are great about seating people but it is getting super busy so call. 
Once you're seated you'll realize despite the high demand for the place it's not crowded at all! Relaxing and fun atmosphere at the same time. Fast service and amazing staff! 
Finally the food and drinks. Once again best Pisco sours. I drank mine in one go it was that good. (No didn't mind the pretty high alchohol content either!).
Secondly the food is pretty good too. Though I would say it is more a supplement for the drinks. 
I would definitely recommend going here ... and can guarantee it will become a favorite pretty soon!
author: Maisha R.

description:
Monday happy hour from 4:30pm until closing?! YAAAAAS. The fried ceviche was delicious, and their Pisco cocktails are really good!

Everyone was very friendly here - definitely coming back!
author: Michael K.

description:
Stopped by for drinks and tapas at the bar before listening to the Ataris at Bottom of the Hill.  Easily walkable from there!
Maria was out bartender, very friendly and attentive.  Had the ceviche with plantation chips, and the scallops.  Pisco cocktails and beers to drink.
Spent over $100 on 4 drinks and 2 appetizers, but the service was great, and we are feeling good, who cares!
author: H Y.

description: Service was good, drinks were good, food was not good and overpriced. $150 for 2 cocktails, 2 starters, and 2 mains would be OK -- if the food was really good. We left half of everything behind. Will not be back.
author: Laura R.

description:
OMG this place is AMAZING, and I don't even like Peruvian food. I didn't have high expectations. I live in the neighborhood, walk by often, and it never seems crowded. Came here for a friend's bday and I will definitely come back. 

We started off with scallops (excellent!). The most amazing dish is the seafood paella. Absolutely delicious, flavorful, and full of seafood (little rice, so not just full of fillers). A tiny bit spicy. My friend had the pork belly, which was good, but not nearly as good as the paella. I'd love to try the seafood bouillabaisse next time. 

We also had the flan and the churros for dessert. Churros were very good. Flan was a bit bitter. 

Really way exceeded my expectations. Most restaurants are mediocre and forgettable. This place is remarkable.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Just went with some friends. I think this place is alright.

The food is very overpriced. $25 for a paella? Sure but I'm expecting it to feed at least two people.

We ordered that as our actual dinner dish and 2 small tapas and another small dish. It turned out to be around $85 for four people. If everyone walked out full I understand but I was still hungry walking out Mochica.

Was the food good? It wasn't bad. But the portions were small. The waiter would come once in a while and ask if everything is ok. That's great.

But I don't think I want to spend $24/person again and walk out hungry.
author: Tim C.

description:
Delicious modern Peruvian food in a trendy ambiance. 

Came here for an early birthday dinner with my family (with reservation) and were seated promptly. In terms of drinks, the pisco sour was tasty! But the chicha morada drink (Peruvian blue corn) was lacking in flavor and came from a bottle. For food, we shared 6?tapas style dishes and 1 dessert between the 4 of us. 

Ceviche (5/5) 
So juicy! This ceviche consists of large chunks of fish, calamari rings, mussels, and shrimp. Sooo flavorful, one of the best ceviches I've had in a while. The seafood is tender and the portion is generous. 

Chicharrones style fried chicken (5/5) 
Similar to Spanish fried chicken-the pieces were small, bite sized but so tender and full of flavor. The batter is not overpowering and the meat to coating ratio is prime. Came with a creamy sauce and a salsa-esque sauce to dip. Would recommend! 

Mushroom empanadas (3.5/5) 
Came with 2 per order and were pretty large. The mushrooms inside were juicy, but nothing to write home about for the skins. 

Paella (4.5/5) 
Tasty and a good amount of seafood in it! But this paella was wetter than most I've had (I prefer a little drier). Regardless, the flavors were there and overall a really good dish. 

Pork belly choufa (3.5/5)
Fried rice with pork belly chunks in a tomato-ey sauce. Flavors were pretty good, but a little too greasy for my taste. Atop the rice there was also a creamy sauce but I think we could've done without. 

Calamari relleno (3/5) 
Personally I think the meat filling should stay in a fried potato ball..not calamari. Still it was an interesting dish to try! Comes in 2 pieces, but I didn't think the flavors were toooo cohesive. 

Churros (4.5/5)
Yum!! Comes with 4, Dulce de lece freshly made churros. The hot chocolate seemed like the actual hot chocolate drink, but I was expecting the melted chocolate. A good way to finish off dinner! 

Overall, a great place to explore different types of Peruvian (fusion) food! Everything was fun to eat and portions were decently sized. A fun place to celebrate an occasion or grab a nicer/a bit more expensive dinner.
author: Robin Y.

description:
This might be my new favorite restaurant in SF.
We tried all the vegetarian options on the menu and every single one of them was so delicious.
The mushroom empanadas were the best I have ever tried so far.

To close it, we ordered alfajores and again, we all were extremely happy with the choice.

We also tried 7 different cocktails among everybody in the table and all of them were so good.
author: Sevda G.

description:
Yum yum! Delicious wine, cozy environment, friendly service.

I came here to grab a drink with friends before watching a play being shown at a nearby black box theater. Was surprised at how popular it is! This is definitely a happening spot.

Service was great. Loved our bartender. 

That said, service is slow. They really take quite awhile to get food served.

Atmosphere is wonderful. It's pretty, vibrant, and alive. It is, however, a bit on the tiny side and feels crowded especially when people start to really show up. It's not the square footage as much as the layout, which by the bar feels super congested. There really isn't much room to walk around, and when you're sitting there you feel the immediate presence of people around you, walking behind you, etc. Claustrophobes might want to avoid this place, in other words.

I heard good things about the chicken here but we didn't have time before our play started - will have to come back and try this another time!
author: Alex G.

description:
TLDR - Some of the best rotisserie chicken I've had (and delicious dipping sauces)!

Ordered pick-up from Mochica, so I can't speak too much on the restaurant itself. It didn't seem too busy around lunch/brunch time on a weekend so it looks like a good spot if you don't like long waits or crowds.

I'd definitely recommend getting their rotisserie chicken! It says it's limited availability on the menu on both Grubhub and their website, so I'd call in advance if you want their chicken to make sure you're not disappointed when you get there.

* POLLO A LA BRASA ($17.50 for half chicken) - 5/5
[rotisserie chicken, served with 2 sauces & choice of french fries or salad]
Quite possibly one of the best rotisserie chickens I've had! And I got it as takeout so that's really saying something. The chicken was incredibly juicy and had a lot of flavor from the seasonings. It's served with 2 dipping sauces - chimichurri and huancaina (a spicy cheese sauce) - both of which were delicious, but I personally preferred the chicken on its own and using the dipping sauces for the fries instead. The cheese sauce was especially addicting. Otherwise, the fries were okay on their own - thick cut with some more crisp than others. The restaurant also surprisingly gave me a small side salad (which I don't think was in my order). It was just some simple greens and cucumber but the passionfruit vinaigrette was amazing!
author: Jessie L.

description:
Service-meh. The lady at the front desk was not friendly. She stared and seemed annoyed when I asked for a table for 2, even though the place was half empty. There was only 1 waitress for maybe 8 tables and it took around 15-20 minutes for her to stop by our table to get our drink orders. Maybe they're understaffed, idk. The busboy did a great job of filling our waters while we waited, but sadly he couldn't take our order. Different runners do bring out the food pretty fast after you order, but pacing wasn't great. At the end, they packed up some of our leftovers and gave us a card to pick up at the front desk. Nice in theory but kind of gross when you realize the next day that half of the food in your bag isn't actually your leftovers. 

Food-I really love Peruvian food and wanted to love this place but the food is more of a 3.5 stars. I don't think the consistency is there. Beef anticuchos were really tender and flavorful. I enjoyed the calamari and the accompanying sauces. Ribs were flavorful but a little too sweet. Hard pass on the empanadas, dry and hard. Lomo saltado was unmemorable. Yuca fries were too hard. I'd much rather go to Limon for chicken/fries or La Mar for pricey ceviche.

Drinks-pisco sours, can't go wrong.

Ambiance-cute inside and love this area of Potrero Hill. Usually no wait or reservations needed, which is a plus.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
This Potrero Hill neighborhood is becoming wild! I feel like 18th street is going to be the place to be in real quick in the city.

Mochica is a prime example of a great Peruvian spot that is arguably the best in the city today. First of all, they have an amazing pisco selection, and I honestly did not even know that pisco was a hard alcohol before coming to this place. The pisco sour is amazing, get it! Now, a small disclaimer, after getting the pisco sample and the sour I was rather sloshed for the rest of the meal, so do not blame me if my review it not entirely accurate.

They have a very large variety of food items to choose from, and honestly we got so much stuff that I can't even remember what was my favorite. But I can tell you everything is full of flavor, and all the savory dishes were a hit. The one big miss was the dessert though, you can pass on it. The churros especially were very boring. 

My next stop here will be for happy hour.
author: Nikita K.

description: Had lunch with a large group to celebrate a friend's birthday.  Parking was easy to find.  The staff was very friendly and accomodating.  The food and service was great!
author: Francis S.

description:
Came here before watching Hamilton on a Wednesday. Street parking in the area wasn't too hard to find and it was free. We made reservations via OpenTable for 5:45pm for 7 people and were seated right away. 

Rotisserie chicken: 4/5. It's $15.50 for half a chicken. It was cooked great, seasoned well and wasn't dry. It also came with two dipping sauces, chimichurri and huancaina, a traditional Peruvian sauce. It also comes with your choice of two sides. Dip the fries in the huancaina suace, it's awesome, especially since that sauce is traditionally served over potatoes. Overall great dish and great value. 

Churrasco 1/5: we had really high hopes for this dish but were pretty disappointed. We asked for a medium rare cook and it came out medium. It was way over seasoned to the point were the seasoning was so overwhelming that you could barely taste the chimichurri when you dip the meat. It was also burnt in some spots and overall, too tough and too chewy. The only good thing was the yucca it comes with. 

Pescado a lo macho 3/5: holy moly the coconut rice this dish comes with is SO good and addicting. The coconut is so pronounced! As for the pescado a lo macho, the sauce was pretty good and comparable to other places I've tried. Had a good consistency and flavor. I did not like the fish filet. It was overcooked and even burnt in spots. The rest of the seafood in the dish was good though. This dish is $21. I get this at my favorite Peruvian restaurant in San Mateo for $14.49. 

Dessert: The churros were $10 for 4 small pieces. It was good and I like how it was filled with caramel, but definitely not worth $10. If I were you, I would order the panna cotta instead. It was super refreshing, light, and tasty!

Service: Our waitress was friendly, helpful, and patient. However, at one point one of the workers propped opened the door that was literally right next to our table. I wasn't sure why because it was freezing and the breeze was blowing directly at us, so I closed it. Then she came back and opened it again, telling me to not close it because other  customers sitting far from the door were feeling warm. So our table had to stay sit there uncomfortably cold. I felt bad for the people who were warm and we were on dessert and going to leave soon, so we just hurried and finished so we could leave. But maybe they should have air conditioning or something to control the overall temp of the restaurant.
author: Lexi R.

description:
Was incredibly disappointed by this place. I've had Peruvian in Peru and NYC, plus at the Limón spot on Valencia, and this place pales in comparison. 

Lomo saltado: 3 stars. I'd maybe rate it four stars if I hadn't tried much better at other spots. Portion was on the small side given price. 

Rotisserie chicken: 1 star. Was lacking flavor and dry. Limón has much better, juicer chicken. 

Fries: these were great, 5 stars 

Pulpo (octopus): 2 stars. Flavor was good and the sauce had a nice heat, but as it was baby octopus, there wasn't much meat, but they were abundant in quantity. 

Price: pricey, but wouldn't have mattered if the quality was good, but overpriced given the lack of quality. 

I'm surprised this place has a 4 star rating and Limón has 3.5 stars. Try them both.
author: Dave R.

description:
Another restaurant in the Potrero Hill area that I can rave about!  This area is quickly becoming one of my favorite places to dine at!  Just like many of the other surrounding restaurants, you can also expect good food and friendly service at Mochica.  Reservations recommended.  It was super packed by 7 PM on a Friday.  About the food...

You MUST GET the Calamari Relleno (calamari stuffed with chorizo and sauce).  OMG, THIS WAS SO GOOD.  This was for sure my favorite dish of the night.

Other dishes we tried included the Papa a la Huancaina (the potatoes were good and the bacon was a nice addition, but there were small pieces of olives in it, and I hate olives.  :c), Pollo a la Brasa w/ fries (YES - the cheese and chimchurri... YES YES YES.  Only thing is that the chicken was a little over cooked for my liking, it was almost too soft, but nonetheless still very tasty), Grilled Asparagus (had a nice spiced seasoning to it and I liked the cheese that came with it, tasty side - recommended!), and as for desserts.... we had the churros & lava cake.  My roommate and I got suckered into it.  They're good at upselling you here, lol.  Churros were tasty but I would've liked them to be crispier and the lava cake was kinda just alright.  The ice cream that came with it was good though.

To be honest, I guess after actually writing down my review, the food we had was maybe more like a 3.5/3.75 than a 4.  The only thing that was about 4.5 was the Calamari Relleno which again I highly recommend.  I think it was just the ambiance and the good company that made it a fun night, so rounding it up to a 4!  There's still a lot of dishes I haven't tried, so I'm sure there's more tasty things I just haven't had a chance to try yet.
author: Carena N.

description: I loved the HH at this Peruvian restaurant. We started off with a Peruvian cocktail resembling a margarita but it was made with Pisco & a liquid derived from purple corn. Very tasty.  Next up was calamari and Maria even took the tentacles out for me. We also tried a fried chicken dish with French fries - so yummy.  Conversing about my travels in Peru and the taste of a Pisco Sour and low and behold - Maria whisked up a sample for us. Very enjoyable evening thanks to Maria who attended to our every need. Thank you!
author: Lori C.

description:
This is such a cute restaurant in Portero Hill! I had just arrived back to San Francisco after living in Illinois for a while and this was such a nice treat to remind me the beauties of SF dining. ;) 

We started with a round of sangria. This was so delicious! I love how refreshing it tasted. We then shared the tuna tartare and papa a la Huancaina. The tuna tartare was our favorite. It was perfectly soft and the textures of the avocado and hominy fit the dish really well. I like how there were plantain chips too. We devoured this! The papas were also very good. I enjoyed the smokey and grilled flavor of the potatoes and the Huancaina sauce was the same as my Peruvian's friend's mom used to make. The added bacon pieces were soooo delicious. We got the seafood paella and the pollo saltado. The seafood was good but the paella was probably a little too runny for me. I've had a lot better but this is a Peruvian restaurant.. It was like a fusión paella. I'd pass on this. 

The pollo saltado was perfectly flavored! Finally we ended w churros and this was overall very delicious. I'm glad we checked this place out! Great first meal back in San Francisco.
author: Natalie M.

description:
I've lived in SoMa almost since the turn of this century and didn't even know Mochica was where the Persian restaurant Anar currently resides on that isolated stretch of Harrison between 5th and 6th Streets where cars buzz onto and off of the freeway. Not a fun spot. However, they took over the former Rocketfish space on Potrero Hill about 2-1/2 years ago. I suggested it to Jamie W. since I've been to their sister operation in Walnut Creek, Parada New Peru (review: http://bit.ly/2sn44xW) and thought a little Peruvian would be nice for a change. It was pretty packed on a Thursday evening, and the hostess was the type who gave us small-mouth when she talked while she looked right past us. I hate that.

Anyway, the moment we were seated, we received the bad news that they were out of the $15.50 Pollo a la Brasa. Say what? It was only 7:30PM, and they were out of their signature dish. Damn. We waved the server away as we composed ourselves, all the while munching on the oil-lacquered corn kernels left for us to Hoover (photo: http://bit.ly/2tzDx04). Jamie decided to be the more adventurous one and ordered the $19 Aji de Gallina, which was a shredded chicken breast braised in an aji amarillo sauce which was intensely creamy. It came with diced potatoes, Botija olives, jasmine rice, and half a hard-boiled egg on top (photo: http://bit.ly/2rCXWol). It was tasty comfort food albeit heavy on the carbs.

I ordered the $22 Seafood Paella which put a Peruvian twist on a Spanish favorite by using a saffron-pimento sauce over the bomba rice. Mussels, clams, shrimp, and calamari were mixed in to make it a most seaworthy dish topped with red onions for a bit of crunch (photo: http://bit.ly/2teQRaE). It was also tasty in a starchy, no-frills kind of way and genuinely satisfying. Surprisingly the high point of our meal was the $7 Grilled Asparagus with a creamy aji-style sauce for dipping (photo: http://bit.ly/2tescTP). So I guess we eventually got over our pollo withdrawal, but it took plenty of carbs and cream sauce to do it. We would come back, but I think I'll call ahead to see if poultry is still in da house 'cause I loves me some rotisserie chicken.

FOOD - 4 stars...no pollo a la brasa but what we had was hearty, tasty fare
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...crowded and bustling, filled with people eating my chicken
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...hostess was not the mostest but the server was attentive
TOTAL - 4 stars...good Peruvian is harder to find than you think and this place does it
author: Ed U.

description:
I had been on the road for two weeks, four destinations, all in Asia, all work. I was worn out and beaten down. The sheer volume of work was unbearable and everyone knows that I work all the time. I had been warned before I took the job. But I knew this was the future I had been waiting to enter so no complaints, except for the heat. It's freaking hot everywhere I went and super crowded, imagine the pleasant surprise when I came back, and to this. Giants game was on. Quiet spot for brunch. Sun was beaming down. Great cocktails. Bright and happy paint and perfect lighting. I could go on about how great the place is, but at the end of the day it was really how quiet this neighborhood made me happy. I simply do not want to see anyone, be around anyone. Restaurant like this, they don't make them like this in Asia. 

The dishes are really fantastic. But the cocktails for brunch were better! The ceviche mixto is great paired with a refreshing cocktail. The fried rice dish was amazing and so were the yucca fries. 

Unlike many places in city where it gets crowded over the weekend for brunch, I think this spot is great for a casual gathering without stress.

We don't spend enough time with friends. We don't spend enough time savoring idle moments of the early summer mornings. This place is great for both. 

Do come!
author: Victoria E.

description:
I've been to Mochica twice, which says a lot since I get weird about going somewhere more than once (too much food to try, too little time!). But I really like the food here, hence why I didn't mind a second visit and the reason why I planned my friend's surprise birthday dinner here. 

Go here for a normal dinner. However, don't come here to celebrate special occasions involving a lot of people, especially surprise birthday dinners. The service was terrible. 
 
1. The host basically ruined the whole surprise even though we told her beforehand that the birthday girl was arriving later and that it was a surprise. 

"Hi, I have a reservation at 8pm for Laverne."
"How many?" 
"For two" *WINK WINK* 
She looks confused.. "for 8..?" 
"No, for two." *WINK* 
Still confused.. "for 8..?"

2. We tried to make our server's life easier by dividing the group into separate checks prior to ordering. She divided our checks, but also managed to charge everyone's card to the wrong check. 

3. We gave her candles to put on the cake but she didn't use all of them.. lol. 

BUT, I do like the food here: 
- Ceviche (pescado or chino)
- Yucca fries!! omg so fluffy
- Scallops Carlitos - quinoa crusted Day Boat scallops 
- Seafood paella

I'd MAYBE come back on an occasion where no surprises are involved.
author: Laverne N.

description:
Amazing! I went after work on a Thursday with some friends and had an incredible time. For happy hour it was not very packed but it started to fill when we left around 7.

Started with the Ceviche and some other appetizers which were very tasty and I had the Chaufa Pork Belly for my main. It was incredible! Perfect amount of spice to get my face a little red but not overly uncomfortable, perfectly seasoned, as well as the Pork Belly and rice was delicious.

I tried the Pisco Sour cocktail which was very interesting with the added cinnamon, I'd definitely recommend. It was my birthday week also and they brought out two cookies with a candle as well as a mini - Pisco Sour shot which was very thoughtful! If in the neighborhood I would definitely try to stop by again.
author: Matthew O.

description:
Uber is about the only way your gonna get me to eat in this neighborhood. Parking is like a nightmare.
Made reservations. I love to do that because most places have lines outside the door . Friday night Peruvian food. 

This is an excellent way of getting your fix. Felt kinda rushed in the beginning, but just asked for a little more time to go over the menu. Or you can just open Yelp and look  at the pictures and show your waiter. I think the most expensive thing is $25. 
The price is worth it. The quality and the taste of the food , is worth it. We ordered too much. So we had leftovers. 
They gave us a card  to pick up our food after we finished at the table.
author: Jesse S.

description: We had the pleasure of eating lunch here on a Saturday afternoon. Great food and service. The quality of produce was on point!
author: Joseph B.

description:
The food was an easy +5 stars, the only reason why I am rating this 4 stars is due to the hostess who was pretty rude to us from the minute we entered the restaurant. When we first came in, even though the restaurant was pretty empty she insisted that we sit at the last two seats at the bar. After our appetizers we asked if we could move to a different seat at the bar, which was higher, and she rudely said "yeah sure, sure."

The dinner/actual food here is thoroughly impressive though! It is definitely a little more expensive (average of about $17 a plate), but it is worth it.

We got started with the ceviche chico which is ceviche with ahi tuna as well as a moscato and a pisco sour. The pisco sour was amazing and I would recommend ordering it as your drink! The ceviche chico was great as well and had a hearty amount of ahi tuna chunks in it.

Following that, we ordered a mushroom empanada. Inside the empanada was some cut up steak along with mushroom. The outside was crisped perfectly as well.

Our main entree was the saltado which was this plate that had steak, tomatoes, fries and a side of rice as well. Extremely filling and tasted amazing!

Overall minus the hostess' attitude, the food and drinks are great and I would definitely come back!
author: James D.

description:
The service was impeccable. The food was fresh and flavorful. First time having ahi tuna ceviche. It was yummy. Enjoyed lomo salgado, anticuchos sauce was good. 

The flavor for the chicken could have been stronger. Seafood dish with plantain chips. Sangria is well known here and good. 

The location is hip and upbeat.
author: Janice L.

description:
I came here with low expectations, having eaten at their sister restaurants and left underwhelmed.  I am happy to say that Mochica was able to turn my impression to a positive note.    My party of 4 came here for dinner on a Saturday night.   I did find the service to be slow, but that may have been due to management. 

We shared the ceviche pescado and the pulpito a la parilla (octopus). My main was the 1/2 chicken.    Of the 2 shared appetizers, the octopus dish was my favorite. The baby octopus were cooked tender and seasoned right.

I really enjoyed the chicken. The chicken was cooked tender and the meat moist and not dry. The seasoning of the chicken was very good.  I have to admit, much better than Costco rotisserie chicken. I should have ordered a whole chicken to take the leftovers home. 

Overall a nice dining experience, where my expectations were surpassed.
author: Marck N.

description:
The food was mostly decent but the service was saddeningly very surface-y. What do I mean by that? So first off - the food. Main complaint is that everything was like lukewarm. I feel like cooked food is meant to be either served hot or cold but not this weird lukewarm temp that we got our beef hearts and fried rice in. I would have asked the waiter but we could only get his attention for roughly 5 seconds each interaction and I ended up feeling badly calling him over because he seemed to be in such a rush all of the time. My suggestion would be to slow down and serve your customers completely instead of showing up and barely giving them a chance to speak.

The front desk staff was also particularly unhelpful - having me sit at the (cold) door while I waited a few min for my friend instead of our table that was already assigned and empty, in a not packed restaurant. Oh well, probably not coming back but the food was fine. Next.
author: Neechi M.

description: What a great find! The ceviche Chino was the absolute best I have ever had. Honestly so disappointed we dont live closer. This place has amazing flavorful food and a fun bar!
author: Hope G.

description:
3.5 stars

Good pisco sour, cute location in Potrero, fresh seafood. Mochica is a great place to get drinks and some apps. However, it will cost you a pretty penny. Our group of 5 ordered a round of drinks with a few small plates to share and 2 desserts. Bill came out to almost $45pp before tip! The food was good but I literally had a few bites of a few dishes lol. Needless to say, I was still a bit hungry after leaving dinner but of the food I did taste, flavors were unique and service was good.
author: Yin H.

description:
Beat the crowds and come to this cool spot tucked away in Potrero Hill where you can enjoy dinner among locals in this booming little neighborhood. 

The extensive menu offers a unique fusion of Peruvian, Asian, and Southern flavors. Somehow, Chef Carlos Altamirano makes it work!

The bartenders can make you all the Pisco cocktail variations to pair w the classic staples like the ceviche and lomo saltado- but the menu keeps going and it keeps making your mouth water after every entry. You'll love the crispy pork spareribs, bacon mac n cheese, even the blue chips with spicy dipping sauce. All exploding with flavor. 

Come during Happy Hour for a great deal. 

If you're not in the mood for Pisco, try their sangria. 

For the designated driver and kids, try the chicha morada- a traditional, non-alcoholic purple corn drink that is tart and sweetly delicious.
author: Mitzi G.

description: Over priced, unfriendly inattentive waitstaff and greeters. The ethnic food mixes they try to do aren't graceful or delicious. Do not recommend.
author: Zoe M.

description: Food is excellent but service is mediocre. A bit pricey for tapas, but the quality is worth it.
author: Kristin S.

description: Loved the location; heading to the top of Potrero Hill. Beautiful ambience. Sits a good number of people compared to the other food spots in that area and the staff is welcoming. Our waiter was friendly and efficient and our food was brought out quickly. Decent drink selection. Reasonable prices. It's upscale so you want to wear something nice. Great spare ribs! And great ceviche. I'm glad I chose to spend my dinner date here
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
Great vegetarian AND alt. vegan options, lovely ambiance and service, yummy sangria and cocktails, overall good times.

Nestled atop the quiet, sunny, charming Portrero Hill, this place has everything I look for in a go-to restaurant spot. I've eaten here at least a handful of times, and it's easy to see why I keep coming back. 

I'm absolutely smitten by their Yucca fries, and all of the other super rich and delicious starter plates.  The Tequenos manage to be savory AND sweet cheesy fried goodness (Oaxacan cheese, avocado in a crispy wonton? YES. GAWD). Seriously some of the best comfort food I've ever had. I haven't gotten to all their starter plates yet, but there are so many options!

As a vegetarian, the Quinoa Risotto was my go to dish, and if I was in the mood for something smaller, I'd go for the mushroom empanadas. As a recent vegan however, the waitress (who was also vegan!) was super friendly in helping me find some plates that could be made animal-product free! I ended up getting the Lomo Salteado sans the beef and swapped the regular rice for their delicious coconut rice.

I'm so happy that I discovered this place, it continues to be top of mind for me and my friends when we're hungry and in the area. There's ample seating, good drinks, a spacious and charming dining room that never gets too noisy. I will 100% be back and would definitely recommend this place, especially if you're looking to try Peruvian food!
author: Jackie K.

description:
I've eaten at their sister restaurant in Walnut Creek and I wasn't that impressed. However this location was different. I actually liked the food here. For our appetizers we had the ceviche pescado  and the baby octopus. The servings were a little small but the flavors were good. They have some interesting drinks as well. I ordered a blueberry drink (forgot the name) but I found it to be a little too sweet so I switched with my friend, who had a pisco drink , which tasted like a margarita. 

My main course was a aji de gallina. It had some spice and heat to it, which was different from the aji de gallina I've had in Peru (which was mild). I quite enjoyed it. 

I would come here again.
author: Kenson K.

description:
This place was absolutely amazing, came here for Valentine's Day and it did not disappoint.

The Food:
We ordered the Cebiche Chino, Beef Heart skewers, Empanadas de la casa, and Pulpito a la Parilla.

The Cebiche Chino's sauce was on point. I'm assuming the name comes from the sauce, because it sort of resembled a sweet and sour sauce you would find at Chinese restaurants. Take that resemblance with a grain of salt, it's a must try.

Beef hearts are smoky and spiced well; have a little kick to them, which is totally fine by me.

Empanadas, as the name suggests, are made in-house. The sauce elevates it to a whole new level and can be split between two people if you're looking to do a tapas style dinner. 

Pulpito a la Parilla, if you like octopus, just order it. Not even going to bother describing how good it is.

For drinks: pisco sour and some spicy/smoky drink (both were awesome)

The Service:

The hostess, Gabi, eh...maybe she was just bummed she was working on Valentine's Day. She directed us to the bar when we arrived a half hour early just to check in, after I said we had a reservation. But then she sat a large group right away after we sat at the bar, which was odd...seeing as how the restaurant had just opened. She was the only not so great part of the evening. Sol and Jorge (the managers) were very nice as was our server, who was also named Jorge. 

OH, and if you're there to take advantage of happy hour, you MUST be seated at the bar. Kind of lame, but not a deal breaker.

Conclusion:

Come to Mochica, it's an awesome spot with amazing dishes.
author: Aaron C.

description:
My family's from Peru - and this place doesn't stand the test. The hostess is not polite here, and the lomo saltado was mediocre. It's $21 yet cooked with frozen potatoes (not freshly sourced as the restaurant menu says). The lomo saltado is also not authentic. It's served with a tomato stew that tastes as if it was made from canned tomatoes. The dish is cooked traditionally on a wok and is of Chinese-Peruvian origin, so although I appreciate inventive twists on a classic, cooking experiments have to land well on the palate to be effective. 

Truth be told, the worst quality of this place is that it's overpriced. I thought Limon was expensive, until I saw the $20 ceviches at Mochica. I didn't bother ordering - I'm sure they are tasty, but their service has to improve by ten if they want to charge $20 for a small plate of ceviche. 

The presentation and decor itself are pleasant - better than Fresca, but the quality of the food is not nearly as good.
author: Marco H.

description: Amazing salmon Bouillabaisse, rose sparking, bar & kitchen staff - just kinda loving my hood
author: Caroline L.

description:
Went in w/out  a reservation at 7:00pm on a Friday night, barely had room for two at the bar. Ambience is lovely, crowd is local and diverse. We started with yuca fries, yum!, and a tasty pisco drink. Quinoa Risotto for the entree, so smooth, unique and satisfying. Finished with the panna cotta, dang - so good. Like a lighter softer cheesecake, can still remember it two weeks later. 

Can't wait to go back, this is a new favorite.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
For the love of god... this place is fantastic. Precisely because:
Everything was flavorful and plenty. Dishes were beautiful and juicy, and Pisco sours so easy to down.

I recommend u try this place whether or not u enjoy Peruvian food. The tastes were internationally agreed upon yumz.

The atmosphere was also lots of fun.
The serves was great and we loved our server however they kept ln forgetting to bring out the rice, the spoons, etc etc  but we were having a nit too much fun to care!
author: Mary N.

description:
I used to dine at Mochica in SOMA back in 2009 until 2013 and I always had a great impression of the food quality and I really like the mid-upscale atmosphere there. 

Recently I came back to Mochica and I just realized the location is now in Potrero Hill and when I walked in... the interior and the atmosphere were very casual. 
Not only that, the waitress I had was super slow, not knowledgeable and not so smart (sadly).
The restaurant only had 1 table filled with 2 guests when we came in, the rest of the tables are empty and it was about 8:30pm, the time when they shouldn't expect more guests coming.
The staff tried to sit us in a small table near by the door and window which we felt cold, so we asked if we could get a bigger table. Before she sat us to a bigger table, she stared at us with unhappy face.

Then the waitress came, and I mentioned about Mochica in SOMA, she had no idea.
I ordered a glass of sangria, and she asked if I wanted to try a sample, and I said yes. After I drank the sample, she never asked if I liked it and whether I'd like to order a glass. She came back and forth to our table and still did not ask about the glass of sangria.

We ordered several dishes, overall they tasted ok, I also like the portion size. 
The worst dish was the Costillita de Chancho which is crispy pork spareribs, Inca Kola-BBQ sauce, Jicama salad. This dish sounds cool, so we ordered it. But the pork spareribs were super dry, the meat was flavorless, probably had been sitting in the freezer for so long. Basically dried, flavorless meat covered with sauce. I couldn't swallow it and had to spit it out.

I could only wish the waitress was trained, and they should serve a fresh spareribs (not those that had been sitting so long in the freezer).
author: Irene X.

description:
This is the first time income to Mochika and I love it! But they used a wrong tax rate (8.75% instead of 2017 SF sales tax rate) on my bill that upset me on billing.


Came to the restaurant and they had no available table and I sat at community table. I ordered the pisco sour. The drink came at a great balance with  egg white foam. It was fantastic Peruvian drink.

We ordered seafood paella pork shoulder. 

Pork shoulder was very tender and the sauce was spicy and flavorful. Seafood paella was even better. Unlike Spanish type paella, Peruvian is moist and spent less time to prepare. There were many seafood like calamari mussel and shrimp. At one point I think the seafood is more than the rices sauce was tomato base with spice yet the rice was not too soft. I love chewy rice.

We ordered churro as dessert. It s a must. Four pieces $10 and with a small cup of hot chocolate with spice. I would hope they use the filling as the hot chocolate because the real hot chocolate is too dissolved.

When I checked their billing, I think they are wrong. I checked BOE and the official sales tax decreased to 8.5% but Mochika still uses 8.75% on my bill. I am not too pleased since restaurant has the responsibility not to mislead customer. It is not intentional but I think the restaurant better fixes earlier than later in 2017. 

Overall I like this restaurant. Will think to come back
author: Stephanie H.

description: One of my favorite Peruvian food places in San Francisco. They have an awesome selection of ceviche, some of the best salads you will find in town, and delicious drinks. The wait staff here is super attentive and it's usually pretty easy to make a reservation. If you can make it past the grouchy lady at the front of the restaurant, the rest of the experience will be worth it.
author: Michael B.

description:
This is easily the best Peruvian restaurant in SF! We ordered several items from the appetizer, main entree and dessert options and everything was DELICIOUS. The mushroom empanadas and the quinoa crusted flan both sound like they would be "meh" tasting (or weird in the case of the flan) and turned out to be flavorful favorites. Also, couldn't tell there was quinoa in the flan. 
I'll definitely be back and would highly recommend Mochica!
Sidebar - our waiter was also funny, outgoing and helpful completing a fantastic dining experience.
author: Yolande S.

description:
We just had a boys night out here with 6 MEN. It got so lit with the whole chicken and the pisco taster! 
We also ordered the ceviche and Yuko fries! 
Server was great and the chicken was amazing! 

We will definitely have a boys night out here again!
author: Justin S.

description:
Great place for a small group get together. 

Service was great and the setting was intimate. 

We came here for a good friends birthday party and ordered as we were hungry. Each dish was perfect for our table of 6 to each have a bite. The entrees of chicken and steak were perfect for us keto folks but the French fries and sides were all delicious. Each dish had sauce on the side too! 

The only dish that we didn't like was the alfajores. Too much flour and not enough butter and it tasted like cooked flour. 

The best dish of the night was the flan and the steak with chimichurri sauce. It was cooked perfectly medium rare and charred a bit on the outside. The flan was not too sweet and perfectly creamy. I would go back here just for the flan. We all fought for the last bits! 

The okay dishes were octopus, as the blue potatoes were not flavorful and the sauce wasn't to our liking. The scallops were large but seemed previously frozen. 

We saw that they had free plantains chips and when we asked we were told only at lunch. Kinda disappointed. 

Wine prices were good and selection was nice. Would come back here for the steak and flan.
author: Jen C.

description:
I'm all about family-style eating and I feel that Latin foods are the easiest to do that with. 
Mochica was a cute corner spot with a pretty extensive menu full of options for everyone and my friends and I enjoyed everything that we shared and I wished I remembered what we ate haha. 
Service was great and quick; the only thing I wish would've been better was that once our server thought we'd eaten our fill (we still wanted dessert) they closed us out and we had to flag down a different staff member to ask if it was okay to order desserts and coffees. It was, but it was a little uncomfortable having to do so. Apart from that, everything was great and I recommend enjoying this spot for lunch sometime :)
author: Gabby G.

description: Great pisco sour and an even better welcome into the city from Gerardo. Will definitely be back!
author: Mariam B.

description:
This is the best restaurant in San Francisco. There I said it, I challenge anyone to go here and not thoroughly enjoy the food. I'm writing this review after going to Mochica back to back days. 

The restaurant is spacious, great bar, spacious bathrooms and great customer service. 
The food is out of this world insane, the flavors that are developed in each dish is unique and just damn good. I won't limit myself to having a favorite dish because everything I've had here stands out on its own. From the incredible ceviche options, to the rotisserie chicken!! Limon is famous for their roasted chicken, Mochica has better rotisserie chicken. 

This is a hidden gem in San Francisco and I'm glad I've recently discovered it. I wish I could give this place 20 stars it's worth it and then some.
author: Mark B.

description:
This place is really good. I went there one night with my girlfriend and the cebiches were cooked to perfection. Just enough 'leche de tigre' so the fish is not overcooked. They also had a couple of creations not typically part of Peruvian cousine that showed an innovative hand and willingness to experiment that is always welcomed. When done right, it could be the highlight of the evening. 

The wine selection was also good and the staff was very friendly. Mochica is perfect for a first date if you want to impress your date. 

Disclaimer: I am Peruvian and I don't easily give high marks to Peruvian restaurants.
author: Rodrigo B.

description:
I'm giving Mochica 5 stars because they did an awesome job dealing with our 11 person table for a work party.

We decided to throw an anniversary dinner here for one of my coworkers and it was an awesome time! Our waitress was super friendly, and also very understanding and upbeat considering she was dealing with a disorganized group of 11 people. She totally kept her cool! We ordered so many appetizers that continued to arrive throughout our stay at the restaurant. They also took our cake in the back and can cut it (small fee). 
The food was pretty good! I loved the mushroom empanadas, and the chicken skewers were also delicious! I tried this tasty non-alco drink made from corn which was sweet but so different! 
For dinner I ordered the Chicken in an Amarillo sauce, and it was pretty excellent! When it was time for the cake they brought it out with candles, and then cut it, everything was seamless! 
Overall the evening was a blur, but the food was good, staff was great, and a good time was had by all!
author: Larissa S.

description:
Oh my god!!!  YES!!!  Absolutely one of the worlds best restaurants I have ever had the pleasure of visiting and gladly spending lots of money at.  Everything is made fresh that day.  Sauces are either extremely fresh or made within the last 48hrs.    

The staff are beyond friendly and willingly go the "extra mile" for customer satisfaction.  The food is amazing!!  The flavors will dance in your mouth!!!  I have never had a bad meal or a bad experience...even when waiting in line outside.

I can't wait to find an excuse to visit this restaurant again.  They even take American Express.
author: Desmond M.

description:
Great experience as usual!! 
We loved the Pisco sour, ceviche and paella!
Great service too.
author: Serena Z.

description: Good food. I had the ceviche and it was fresh. If you just care about the food then you should try it. However, if you avoid cooking at home to experience a restaurant then the service is less than mediocre and for an average price of $50 dollars/person not taking american express is really annoying.
author: Jose F.

description:
Decent food overall, and probably worth visiting once, but nothing outstanding. Here's what I had:

- Ceviche Pescado: I don't have much of a comment here. They were fine? Nothing overwhelming in terms of flavor -- just some white fish with a hint of lemon.

- Yucca fries: again, pretty much exactly what you would expect. Texture-wise, the interior was good in that it avoided the powder trap that most fries fall into.

- Lomo Saltado: really tasty, actually. The meat was well-prepared, the fries were nicely crispy, and the sauce strongly complimented the dish. If Mochica served more dishes like this one, I would happily upgrade my review to four stars.
author: John L.

description:
This is a 3.5....bumped to 4. 
Food good, not great. ... 
vibe easygoing,
service pleasant, but not attentive.

Ordered 8 dishes.1 horrid (calimari ...5 were good.....2 were great (mac &  cheese and cheese & avacado empanada)?....
author: Sharine d.

description:
Ban Mochica!! Never again!!! 

S: I've been here many times, but this was atrocious tonight. Waited over 15 minutes for even a hello, 25 for water, then after giving order to server and only seeing her once, we received WAY OVERCOOKED quinoa prawns (which I've had many times before and were delicious), as well as yucca fries (asked for more sauce - never got it). We spent the entire meal with no attention, bad food, and when I spoke to a "manager," she rolled her eyes continually. 

Short version: for $47+ (two apps, one glass of wine), being ignored and disrespected, I WILL NEVER COME BACK! This is on top of it being A's birthday yesterday and us grabbing a bite before a concert. 

OHHHH, and then the server had the audacity to grab A's arm in front of me (S) to "wish" him happy birthday. STEP THE F OFF!! Don't touch him!! Way weird and NO!!

STAY AWAY! If only because after 10+ years working in the service industry, they don't deserve the business.
author: SA S.

description: Food is really good, but portions are small and I find a little too pricey. Waitstaff and bartenders are great. Pico sours are legendary.
author: Katrina W.

description:
I've been here a couple times, both times in a group of 6, and both times Mochica did not disappoint. 

Group Faves: Ceviche Mixto, Aji Chicken, Pork Belly rice, and Lomo Saltado.

Runners up: Pork Shoulder, Tequenos (fried oaxacan cheese), fried plantains, and chicken empanada.

With food and drinks it ended up being around $60 per person.
author: Lisa M.

description:
I tracked this place down after they closed shop in SOMA and found out they ended up in Potrero Hill. Nice new look and fortunately the food didn't change along with the location. 

I like their Pisco Sour as it has that nice cinnamon aroma on top and a smooth finish. I've always gotten good service and haven't had a bad dish yet (see pictures). Every time I always have to get the the chorizo and/or mushroom empanada as well as the yucca fries with whatever I'm ordering for an entree. 

I recommend bringing some friends since this is the kind of place where you will want to be able to sample as many dishes as possible in which groups are the best way to do it.
author: Norris T.

description: Came here on a whim while looking for a place to have bunch and cocktails. Popped in and was pleasantly greeted by Gererdo the bartender. Chose to sit at the bar and ordered some cocktails, sweet potato fries and pork belly fried rice (amazing!). We ended up doing the pisco tasting flight as well and Gererdo was very helpful in explaining the different piscos and went above and beyond to make the tasting experience that much more enjoyable. We will definitely be back and recommend this spot to anyone looking to try new things and enjoy great cocktails. Thanks Gererdo!!
author: Lauren S.

description: Had dinner here last night. So hard to choose, there were so many good dishes on the menu! We will have to come back again. We had the seafood paella dish and salmon dish and both were excellent. I've been searching for some really good paella in the city and I think I found it here! Could not forget about the dessert and drinks. The sweet Sangria and the Flan with toasted quinoa hit the spot and was perfect.
author: Joanna I.

description:
Mochica is good solid 3 stars, located in the cute part of Potrero hill next to Mac Daddy and Chez. I loved the decor and would recommend to try except parking might be hard if you're not lucky. Having conversation might be tough since music was too loud. 

Service was par. When we first came I didn't find them too welcoming however the server was good.

We tried the following:

Food
Aji de Galina - good no complaints 
Chicharon de Pollo - good except I think they need to replace the oil 
Pescado a lo macho - would have been perfect if the salmon was not salted. I thought it made the whole think too salty. 
Steak (parilla) - tender beef and the sauce was perfect
Seafood paella - different version from other paella I had. This one is good but more soupy

Drinks - sexy spicy and smoky was tasty (4 stars).
author: Kay D.

description: I absolutely love this place! My go to spot when I'm on this side of the city. I have been here a few times now and never have been disappointed! I thigh last night would be hard to find good recipes since I'm vegan now, but the grilled asparagus and coconut rice were delicious! Plus our group shared a pitcher of the sangria!!! So good must make this your first stop when looking for excellent Peruvian food in SF!
author: Kira I.

description: I came to Mochica with some friends for a birthday dinner and made sure to make reservations two weeks in advance. The location is nice, ambiance is great and the food yummy. Throughout our appetizers and main dishes we were interrupted several times by the bus boy trying to clear out of plates when we still had food on them! We initially didn't let this bother us and just let him know we were still working on it, but when he tried clearing our seafood paella plate that was still a quarter full, we realized they were trying to hurry us up. I understand this place is busy and it was prime dinner time, but I made this reservation weeks ago and we are having a birthday dinner with friends who drove here from all around the Bay Area! Once the bill was paid and the tip was given, the hostess came to our table and seriously asked us if we could leave because she has a party waiting for the table. With all of our drinks, appetizers, dinner and dessert we were there for two hours, we absolutely did not over stay our welcome and regardless, you are in the service industry. Shame on you Mochica! I wish I had not already given you the 20% tip on the extremely over priced drinks and meal! So I'm giving you 2 stars for over priced food and a rude staff.
author: A R.

description:
Bar Service Only

Service - Very good, attentive, friendly, and welcoming. 

Interior - Warm and romantic. It was mysteriously nostalgic. Don't bring your kids here. 

Lychee Cocktail - Good, but couldn't taste the lychee at all. The egg white and the milkiness was on point. I wouldn't order this again. 

Gin and tonic - Needed a squeeze of lime upon request, but it was refreshing.
author: Ee Vonn Y.

description: Great atmosphere, friendly staff - and great dishes. Pisco sour reminded me of Peru. Highlights were the tequenos & mushroom empanada. The service was a little long and dishes were a lot on the pricey side but overall a tasty and fun meal.
author: Mishika V.

description:
Meh. Walked into this restaurant thinking the food was going to be delicious but we were wrong. Waited atleast 15 mins before anyone greeted us and took our orders.

Food was alright. We ordered the chicken skewers, Paella, aji de gallina, and pulpito a la Padilla. All dishes were pretty bland. Chicken and pulpito were over cooked and dry, Paella was undercooked and flavorless. We ordered churros and alfajores for dessert and the churros tasted bitter vs sweet and crunchy. The alfajores were the only tasty food item we ordered. 

Most likely won't be coming here again
author: C O.

description:
Food: 2/5
Service: 2/5
Ambiance: 4/5

We were super excited to finally give this place a tried because we really liked the food at La Costanera in Pacifica (their sister restaurant). We made a dinner reservation, we arrived on time and they seated us promptly, but we didn't get any services until 15 minutes later or much throughout our dinner either. We started off with the Ceviche Chino, Yucca Chips, and Lomo Saltado. The Ceviche Chino was okay, the tuna felt fresh but wasn't crazy about the flavor combo (tasted a little like the Chinese sweet chili sauce). The Lomo Saltado was a disappointment, the beef fillet was overcooked, and overall the dish didn't have the unique flavor of Lomo Saltado. If you want really good Lomo Saltado or Peruvian food, try Mi Lindo Peru!!! 

Overall, we're very disappointed with the services and food. Most likely won't eat here again :(
author: Amy L.

description:
Mochica is an AWESOME brunch spot!

We tried to go to brunch at nearby Plow on a Saturday morning...boy was that a huge mistake. Facing a 2+ hour wait, we decided to take a stroll and see what other restaurants were around. That's when we found "Mochica," which is only a block away. It was almost empty, despite being open and having a full brunch menu. We were super hungry, so we decided to give it a go. And wow, what a great find it was!

Plow might be trendy right now, but the food here is so much better, and there are no lines. Most of the dishes are a Peruvian twist on brunch, which equals total deliciousness. We decided to share the "Poached Egg" and a scrambled egg with Peruvian rice and scrambled egg dish who's name escapes me. Both of them were super tasty. The portions were huge, and the sauces (Machica has a TON of different, homemade sauces) were phenomenal. Prices were also very reasonable for San Francisco. Parking is pretty easy as well. 

The next time you are in Potrero Hill and looking for breakfast, skip the hype and give Mochica a try instead!
author: Brian S.

description:
Great Peruvian food.

Loved the Pork belly Chaufa, Tuna Bandidos, and the Maduros.

And they do delivery...
author: David T.

description:
My first time having Peruvian food and I loved it.  I didn't realize there were tapas and mains and I wanted to try them all.  Unfortunately the two tapas we had weren't very great.  Sorry but they were bland.  We got the recommendation from the waiter and they were a fail.  But that's ok cause the mains totally made up for it.  My bf got the seafood paella which he loved so much he didn't even share!  I got the pork belly dish and oh my days it was delicious.  The pork belly was so tender it literally melted in my mouth.  It sat on top a bed of a kind of fried rice mixture and that in all was just amazing.  

If you check in with Yelp you get a free shot of pisco, which I've never had as a shot, and boy did it pack a punch.  Not my fave but hey it was free! Lol

Definitely a cute local place that I will come back to.
author: Nyla K.

description:
Recommended. I am a regular visitor and normally here at least once per week and have been for more than one year. Staff turn over is minimal (a good sign) and the staff works well together as a team. A weekday happy hour (5-6.30) attracts a nice crowd and excellent bar room bites is often enough for an early dinner. Tony, the bartender, is on his game on Thur/Fri nights, keeping the bar clientele happy and a great start of your evening.

I have eaten literally the entire menu, generally all good, though I have my favorites (the beef heart is a must try). It's a cute neighborhood with great views of the city if you stroll up a bit. Worth the effort to get here.
author: Chris K.

description: I have been there twice. The ambiance is cool and low key. You can come here for a simple working lunch or a fancy dinner. It fits all occasions. Food was great and beautifully placed. The Ceviche mixco and seafood paella we ordered are awesome.
author: Shell J.

description: This has to be my new favorite spot for Peruvian good. The restaurant placement and decor is perfect. We tried the yuca fries, lomo saltado, along with the braised chicken. All were perfect and chicha drink was nice and sweet. Perfect for a hot day. Can't wait to bring the rest of my friends and family here
author: Luis T.

description:
Great food. Perfect service.
First, main and deserts were simply delicious!
Planning to come back there one day
author: Gil B.

description:
If you go in with a baby stroller for dinner, please be ready to be treated rudely.  This has happened twice (and i believe they were different hostesses, but I couldn't tell). They hostesses were dismissive, lazy, and definitely not welcoming. Perhaps, you'll be like Aperto in a couple of years.  

I'm not sure why you would do that to Potrero locals.  

I would have given it one star, but the ceviche is pretty decent.
author: Ej E.

description: This is one of my fav Peruvian restaurant in San Francisco.. Food is delicious, services is awesome, what I love the most is the Lomo Saltado and Ceviche. I do like the pisco sour but I rather to have it hand shake than blended.. the restaurant  in general is amazing !
author: Betsy M.

description: Came here for a work dinner. The place is colorful with large murals. The vibe is fun and laid back. The waitstaff was friendly and attentive. They served us water and wine right away after sitting down. The wine was a tangy argentine malbec. We started with ceviche, which was super fresh and perfectly spiced. It was some of the best I have ever had. They made us our own salad because we had so many vegetarians. It was packed full of kale, cheese, tomato, quinoa and maracuja. The lomo saltado then followed which was so savory and rich I can still taste it now. Finally dessert was alfajores which were large and creamy and tasted home made. The staff was fantastic and so accomodating. The food was some of the best Peruvian food I have had in San Francisco. Stop by for a pisco sour and ceviche or a full meal. You won't regret it!
author: Anne S.

description: Love this place. Great drinks. Good service. Nice atmosphere. In a nice part of Potrero. Street has a lot of nice neighborhood spots. The food is fresh and delicious.
author: Roger L.

description:
I can see why it's 3.5 stars. The food is just OK while the pop art-ish contemporary interior and modern twist on classic Peruvian dishes can easily make you a fan. Service was OK and our waitress seemed junior since she didn't know details about the menu. 

Came for a group lunch. They start you off with these purple potato chips with this addictive and acidic salsa that's a change of pace from Mexican salsa

CEBICHE CHINO - PERUANO - $16 - Plentiful ahi tuna while this ginger, scallion, tigre milk, and hoisin sauce concotion was tasty. Toasted nori, sweet yam, and hominy completed the wave of textures and flavors. I'd recommend their toasted plaintain chips to go with. 

MUSHROOM EMPANADA - $9 - Could be a meal in itself since it's a generous portion. Savoriness of the portobellos(?) with the butteriness of the crust was really balanced. I'd get this again. 

PAELLA - $20 - Quick version since I was really looking forward to the crunchy socarrat. Average. 

POLLO SALTADO (instead of lomo/beef) - $17 - Maybe if the thick cut fries were crisped to contrast to the chicken it would be more interesting. The sauce had an interesting twang, maybe maggi sauce to it. It was still good. 

Not classic Peruvian. Still like Fresca a little better. Good for a date night and groups. Will have to check out some of their pisco sours and mojitos at the bar next time.
author: Earl G.

description: The lunch we had was delicious, if a bit pricy since there were only dinner prices. Highly recommend any of the beef dishes including lomo saltado and the fantastic beef sandwich. The aji de gallina was a really bright yellow (resembling a curry) and tasted good, not great. The service was friendly but distracted (our churros were forgotten but amazing after we reminded the server). A good place to go for quality food and fun flavors, especially if on an expense account or at night; for lunch, more for a special occasion.
author: Anita B.

description:
This place is definitely ok! I would recommend it but it's nothing to write home about! I ordered the scallops for the appetizer and they were good! But then again, not incredible! It was prepared in a fancy way and I did appreciate that a lot. 

For the meal I ordered the steak. I probably won't ever order it again, it's a $30 steak and it was very OK. But i guess it's my fault, that's what you get for ordering a steak at a place that is not a steakhouse. 

All the other dishes were good but I think they were more similar to each other than I had hoped. It was all some kind of stir fry type of thing tossed in a peruvian sauce and served with rice. BUT come check it out for yourself!
author: Jason W.

description: Food was just ok. Service was subpar as we were mostly ignored by the waitstaff. Nothing to write home about and a bit pricey.
author: Ron V.

description:
Very good food. Nice ambience. Good service.

I really enjoyed this place. We went here for dinner. We had Ceviche Mixto,  Pulpito a la Parilla, Chancho Adobado, Chaufa Pork Belly, and Tuna Nuovo Andino. The tuna dish was by far the best. Fresh tuna with a lovely a fruity but savory sauce. The place has very nice decor and I like the chill music they were playing.
author: Herb D.

description: It's a delicious neighborhood joint that came highly endorsed by two South American friends. Great menu, good ambiance. Service was lacking - I asked for a less sweet pisco, they said yes and basically ignored me. And we were kind of shooed oiut. But the food was very tasty.
author: Andrew K.

description: We have been going here for a weekend brunch every couple of months for the past year, and the food never disappoints. Everything is really tasty, and the best part there is normally no wait time.
author: Olya A.

description:
Ceviche - refreshingly spicy, especially with the lemon note and texture of the seafood.
Baby Octopus - Now this I likey. Tender and slightly chewy. Grilled octopus is da bomb, even more so when it cooked just right.
Beef heart - The texture! The spice! Chimicuri! *Gooble gooble* We almost had a fork fight over this.
Seafood paella - Honestly, not my dish. It's bland and way too soggy for Paella. It almost match the texture of grits. Yes, it was that soggy.
Peruvian Chicken (chef's recommended) : Ehh...nope! If the paella was bland, this dish was way too salty. It's like they covered the whole chicken in salt rock, or maybe drowned because even the inner meat was still extremely salty. Some may like this overpowered taste. Not us.
Pork Belly fried rice - Decent. Maybe even better if they use different rice that's less starchy.

Ambiance was ok. Decor was interesting. Service was decent.
author: Jenny T.

description: Great neighborhood vibe and would have given the place 5 stars if it were not for the giant screen TV above the bar with garbage (TMZ) on. Super distracting and cheapens the place terribly. PLEASE SWITCH IT OFF!!
author: Marsh M.

description:
I've had Mochica bookmarked FOREVER and finally got to try it last night. It's in an adorable neighborhood and parking was a breeze on a Wednesday. There are two areas, one with a bar and one separate from that where you can see the kitchen. We sat near the kitchen because we had a child. The waitress was ok, but kind of awkward and the restaurant was pretty empty. One thing I loved was that our water glasses were constantly refilled (I drink water like crazy all day, er' day).

We ordered lomo saltado, ceviche mixto, yucca fries, Mac and cheese, plantains and a dish that kind of looked like a curry or something. Everything was good, but the standout was the Mac and cheese. It was creamy and had bacon with shallots(?), so I'd totally order it again. The ceviche was fresh, but pretty standard, and the plantain chips had sugar on them which I didn't care for. I heard the saltado was really good, but didn't try it.

At the end we ordered the churros, which I was super excited for because they looked amazing, but weren't that great. There wasn't much sugar on them and although there was chocolate in the middle, it just wasn't enough. The churros have potential, but missed the mark.

Overall I liked this place, but wasn't so wowed that I need to come back any time soon.
author: Steph L.

description:
I would recommend the paella at this place and the strong Pisco's drinks. Save yourself from the ceviche, while it's fresh, you can find better ceviche at other Peruvian restaurants. Good service though ..
I think it is overpriced, small rationed, and it lacks flavor ..
author: Ale B.

description:
I've been here a couple of times. It's not bad,  but I don't like it as much as other Peruvian places I've been to, and this one is on the pricier side. I found the lomito saltado a bit disappointing, and wasn't impressed by the octopus either, which I usually really like. 
On the other hand, the pisco sours are very good and the staff is very friendly. I may add more stars in the future, not sure yet.
author: Marta F.

description:
We made a last minute move to have our dinner club at Mochica and I'm sure glad we did.  We had an amazing experience and all of the food was delicious!  We ordered the cebiche chino (awesome), plantain chips, carne empanada, chicken empanada, tequenos and mac and cheese.  For main main entree I had the steak and it was flavorful and very good.  We ended the night with churros that people said were the best they've ever had.

Great spot to get together with friends or have a date night out.
author: Blake B.

description: Food with flavor. Mochica has great Peruvian food with tons of flair, be it beef, chicken, or seafood. Make sure to try the pisco sour if you have never had one-- delicious and leaving you wanting another, and another. Which you will end up ordering. Over and over again. For appetizers/shared tapas plates, order the ribs and the yuca chips and the camarón croquante-- so luscious and good. For main plates, make sure to order the lomo saltado and the paella.
author: Bibi M.

description: Mochica was a great dining experience. I had stumbled across the location looking for a celebratory restaurant to enjoy before going to a show at The Midway and this place was the perfect to get in the mood. Starting with the ceviche appetizer and plantain chips, it was the perfect blend of flavor to get me ready for the main course.
