Now perhaps a gringo hipster who has never had this dish might not know better never having had it and think, oh cool, Peruvian food with bacon. 

My wife's pork dish was only ok and tough. Another companion had chicken or turkey albondigas and was underwhelmed, especially when the rice she ordered with it arrived 10 minutes later even though there was only one other table occupied at that time. 

And what did the do to the platanos? They were swimming in some kind of syrup and had little flecks of cheese and drips of something, crema, perhaps. When we asked the host and waiter before ordering they said they were between ripe and green. They were definitely Maduros but the preparation left a lot to be desired. 

We skipped dessert and went directly to Mitchell's to drown our sorrows. What had been an inventive, consistently great Peruvian restaurant has veered into fusion territory that fails. And we didn't even try the Peruvian version of truffled macaroni and cheese with bacon. One wonders who they are trying to appeal to. And it wasn't inexpensive - $40/person not including tip, no alcohol and one person had no meat/seafood.
author: Marco M.

description: This place is incredible! Went here for the first time last night and the rotisserie chicken and beet salad were soooo delicious. I have a severe allergy to soy and they were above and beyond on top of making sure my food was safe for me to eat. Highly, highly recommend to all!
author: K. N.

description: Had dinner here last night with my mom and I can't wait for the next time we're in the city to dine here once again! The food was delicious (and that's coming from someone who is South American and knows the cuisine.) We had the papa a la huancaina, paella and jalea for dinner and for dessert ordered the passion fruit panna cotta and churros con chocolate. Everything was so delicious, we are so happy we found this little gem!
author: Brianna A.

description: Super friendly staff, mega tasty Platano fritto with queso, pan con Championes, fresh mimosas?!? This place rocks. I've never been in to Peruvian food but this place hit the spot.
author: Benjamin S.

description:
Service so slow it would considered poor in Britain
Bland food that was too salty
Frozen chips
Way overpriced, would have been disappointed at half the price
author: Matthew S.

description: We ordered the empanadas, tuna tartare and the beet salad. Everything was delicious. The Smokey Spicy cocktail is definitely delicious, but really intense. I'd recommend adding extra lime juice to cool it down a little. Overall, great experience. I'd definitely come back and recommend this place to others.
author: Brooke D.

description: Friendly staff, delicious food. Highly recommend the lomo soltado!
author: Adrijana G.

description: Not coming back. The ceviche was not good. The flavor was spicy and thats it. Bolitas de Yuca also very bad. This place is pricy for what it is. No worthy
author: Daniela C.

description: My go to Peruvian, but a bit over priced, slow service and loud. I always get the Lomo Saltato and leave happy.
author: Sergio M.

description: We were visiting SF and looking for something new and exciting. Peruvian food sounded interesting and it sure looked good online so we gave it a shot. The food was AMAZING. The flavors burst in your mouth and were so unique I can't even describe them. We got the ceviche to start, my boyfriend and I just looked at each other with our mouths hanging open after the first bite.. it was that good! I got the scallops which were good, I really liked the unique sauces-- but it wasn't off the hook. My boyfriend got the pork shoulder and we once again had the jaw dropping moment, it was so flavorful and delicious. It kind of had a bit of a Mexican feel, but better! Cocktails were great too. Very glad we went here
author: Shannon D.

description: Love it.    Lunch or dinner.   Parking is tough but the food was so worth it.    Service is also excellent
author: Oranee D.

description:
I chose this place for brunch so we could meet up with some friends while we were visiting the states. We chose it because some how the name of the restaurant ended up in my partner's phone messages, but we're still not 100% sure who told him about the place. I was having some problems with the booking online, so a friend called and made the booking under his name. We had a late booking (around 2 pm) so my friends would have enough time to drive up. 

So my partner and I arrive first. We tell the server that we're early (because we were), and that we were here for a booking for 8 people, but now it was 6 as two people cancelled. She looked confused. Then she looks at the booking screen and says, "You're early, we need to get your table set up." (Why I don't know as the place was only about half full, and you would have thought they would have known about a large party). Then a second woman came up and we basically went through the exact same conversation with her. Weird.

Anyway, we sat at the bar and had some drinks while we were waiting. The drinks were nice, but I've had better. They finally got our table set up and let us sit down (even though we were early). Once our friends arrived, we had a bit of catching up and ordered some food.

My partner and I split the tuna ceviche and some beef heart skewers to start and then split the traditional Peruvian rice main (whatever it was called). The food was actually really tasty. The tuna was really delicious and beef heart is always good. The rice was nice, but not completely amazing. We had some more drinks.

I mean this place is alright. The food is good, but the service is a bit weird. I'm not sure I'd come back, but who knows?
author: Grant T.

description:
The food was delicious and the waiter was attentive and playful.

Sangria was sweet and fruity. Loved it.

Cebiche Chino - the tuna tartar was amazing very delicious and in a generous portion.

Cebiche Mixto had a good mix of fish, also good.

The mac and cheese was by far the best I've ever had - it had some leaves of spinach, red onions and shrimp, it was incredibly creamy. 

Russa salad on an avocado was very good, too. 

And, the best was the Churros with dolce de leche filling. I had to fight my kids for it!

It's sad that this amazing new restaurant is rated so badly because "the waiter took too long to fetch their drink".  We were here on a Wednesday night and it was perfect. 

Try this place, the food is worth it! I can't wait to come back and try other dishes!
author: Stacya G.

description: The idea of a Peruvian brunch is genius. Aren't they the country with 800 different kinds of potatoes? Anyway, it's going to be formidable, and hey, you've got your choice of coffee or pisco sour. I'm in love!
author: sarah m.

description: Great meal! Took forever to order because everything on the menu looked great.  With pregnant wife, we unfortunately had to skip the ceviche, so we went with the baby octopus appetizer followed by the roast chicken and spare ribs.  Every dish was amazing.  We normally don't go for roast chicken while dining out, because how unique can chicken be?, but this chicken was so good. The meat was super moist and the seasoning was delicious. Will definitely be returning to try more of the menu.  Oh, great drinks as well.  And Gerardo was a perfect waiter.
author: Christopher R.

description:
This is not the Mochica I loved on Harrison street - don't let the name fool you.

We were so happy to see Mochica open again, so we went there for dinner, yet it was a huge disappointment.

The food was below average - I have been to Peru, hence don't even attempt to fool me with fake Peruvian food. Tasteless ceviche, watery paella, and more...in this place. Yuck! 

The price was very steep given the quality and the portion of the food. The service was mediocre too. 

I will never go back there again. The real Mochica is closed for good in my heart.
author: Kai Y.

description:
Great find in Potrero. Mostly impressed with most of the food and the plating, though you pay for it.

Tequenos: Tasty, but like all fried cheese dishes, need to be eaten quickly.
Calamari relleno: disappointing. Not bad, but not as good as I was hoping -- and small. At $15 for the dish, it was essentially $5/bite.
Scallops: AMAZING. Perfectly cooked, and the sauce didn't overpower the flavor. I will go back just for these.
Picante de Mariscos: solid, not amazing. They didn't skimp on the seafood, and you'll find yourself wishing you had more rice with which to mop up the tasty curry-like sauce.
author: Dan C.

description: Had a group of 5 people. Pretty good service. Lovely menu. Had the churro, beef heart, scallops, pisco sour, fish. Everything was tasty! I would come back
author: Thomas C.

description:
I'm not sure about the other negative reviews.  We easily got a rez for 2 people on a week night.  From the moment we arrived to when we left, the staff was super nice.  

We ordered the a cebiche pescado that came with a bowl of chips, lomo saltado and paella.  Everything was good.  

I really like the interior design.  It feels great and warm.  I'll be coming back. Thanks!
author: Julia H.

description:
I love Peruvian food and was super excited to try Mochica.  My conclusion?  It's a nice space, but take your appetite and your money somewhere else.  

We started with the cebiche mixto.  The acidity was well balanced, but I can say, without reservation, that the cebiches I've had at Fresca in Noe, and La Mar in the ferry building, were fresher, more imaginative, and simply superior.  

We also ordered the empanada with aji de gallina.  It (because you only get one empanada for your $10) was golden brown and looked delicious, but what should have been a simple, satisfying pastry was filled mostly with air - and therefore disappointingly dry - and almost entirely devoid of flavor.  

At the server's recommendation (and at this point I should say that Mochica's attentive and friendly service is its best attribute) we shared the lomo saltado.  This was by far the most flavorful dish we ordered, though I am struggling to understand why this basic dish merits the $18 price tag.  Overhead?  

I think you can do better, Mochica.  In the meantime, I'm heading elsewhere.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Great food! Horribly slow service...except when it came to get the bill. It took a half hour just to get drinks but the food was out immediately. 

The spare ribs were amazing!! All stars go to the chefs!
author: Peter B.

description:
The yucca balls, yucca fries and  maduros were really good. I would highly recommend the mac and cheese and the pork ribs de res. They were sublime. The lava cake tasted like a frozen Trader Joe's  version and the churros were served in miserly quantities. The chips which we paid for (with the ceviche) were stale and the lomo saltado fries were not the best  Very pricey, on par with La Mar. 
The service was nice but long waits...I am guessing the waiter was over-worked so maybe they need to hire more waitstaff. I would probably go to La Mar next when Peruvian craving takes over but it's definitely worth a visit!
author: renu p.

description:
Pah, I'm over it. Here are a few observations:

- Wow, that was expensive ($30 per person) to leave hungry
- Yeah, that was expensive, we didn't even order booze
- Yum. This sauce is tasty.
- Where is the staff? Tuesday night isn't THAT busy
- I wish the sushi restaurant was still here
- This is going on the bottom of our Peruvian list...sigh...
author: Sarah B.

description: Got the special today it was a grilled beef tongue and it was delicious melt in your mouth goodness the sauce was divine!
author: Jordan B.

description: Got an invitation to the soft opening in their new location. Great space on Potrero Hill with excellent food. Very attentive and informed servers. Will definitely be back for more!
author: Robert M.

description:
Welcome to the neighborhood, Mochica!

I was just thinking how it might be unfair to write Yelp reviews for a newly opened restaurant. I like to give them a few weeks to get their service down.  But no need with Mochica.  9pm on a Friday night and the bustling dining room had quick and efficient service.   We literally walked in the door and to our table with our Open Table reservation.  

When I think of Peruvian food, I think of huge, bold flavors.  They deliver on this, but also keep them very well balanced and nuanced.  The flavors are big, but not overwhelming.   Fried items are surprising light.  We finished up the meal with the vegan risotto, which was a perfect, light refreshing way to end the meal.  Leave room for the churros.
author: Troy S.

description:
The menu is so hard to read. Everything is in Spanish (which I don't speak) and the English descriptions weren't very helpful. I asked the waitress how many plates would be adequate for a tapas dinner for 2. She said 3 plates, but it totally wasn't enough food. Did I ask the question wrong?
The food is only mediocre.
author: Kim E.

description:
Lomo Saltado and Chicha Morada

Comfort food I think is litmus test for any Peruvian restaurant. 

Beef was very tender and liked the broth, especially the hint of heat. But disappointed with skinny fries. I'm used to potatoe wedges or at worst steak fries with my Lomo... the skinny fries sort of look more elegant but feels cheap. 

Chicha was good, just wish it was a little cheaper.
author: Derrick L.

description:
Delicious Peruvian Cuisine made with Farm fresh ingredients. Elegant presentation and tantalizing marriages of flavors. 
I had the Lomo Saltado (order with egg!), it's a dish made with tenderloin of beef with onion and tomato with a side of steamed rice.
Extensive yet simple menu with a variety of meats and seafood.
author: Erran A.

description:
So i contemplated between 2 or 3 stars.  It's not that the food isn't good, it's just that...it's a bit expensive and I think they're still working out the kinks.  

On the bright side, the bartender was super cool, explained all their specialty drinks to us.  I don't remember the one that i had, it was with ginger beer though.  We couldn't really taste the difference between the tamarind one and the spicy one that our table ordered, but they were good.  But if I were to get a drink I'd probably get the pisco sour.  Wifester had it, it was good.

The table ordered a combination of:

chicharrones de pollo (chicken thigh app)
costillita de chancho (ribs app)

It was a close vote, but we enjoyed the ribs a bit more.

For entrees we had seafood paella, arroz chaufa (chinese inspired peruvian fried rice!) and chancho adobado (pork shoulder).

They all had good flavor, just nothing that really wowed us or made you want to steal the other person's plate.  The portion isn't huge, but in honesty it's probably the amount of food you're supposed to eat.

we stayed late, like really late.  It was probably almost 11:30 when we left.  They probably hated us on the inside, but were really nice and friendly even when we left.  Much points for being nice.

On the slightly down side

The wait staff is working out the kinks I think.  Now I realize that I am at a peruvian restaurant, but that doesn't mean any of us speak Spanish.  Where the bartender took the time to explain things, the wait staff glossed over things.

when our food came out, the first waiter said seafood paella.  and put it down for those who ordered it.  Then the second waiter came, and he said seafood paella!  we were so confused...turns out the first dish was the fried rice.  Not a big deal.  just kind of funny that none of us were bright enough to say hey where's the seafood in this paella...

Later when the pork shoulder came out, we asked if it was the pork shoulder.  Incorrect Seafood paella waiter said, "it's the chancho adobado", which ok maybe we should've remembered the name of it...so we asked again, does that mean pork shoulder?  and he again says chancho adobado, before i think realizing we weren't getting it and says oh yes pork shoulder.  Again not a big deal.

Also got the churros which were really highly rated.  Was a bit disappointed in this, maybe it's because they have filling they don't hold up as well when you bite into it.  It shatters and you're left to eat small pieces like hanover pretzel pieces.

Lastly, and probably again due to my ignorance/not being smart enough to use google translate, when I think Peruvian (maybe I'm biased), it means an awesome rotisserie chicken to me.  It's on the menu, but apparently as wifester later pointed out to me, "el special del fin de semana" seems to mean "weekend special".  So i was pretty bummed that I didn't get to have it and I am not sure if we'll be going back.

Give em a try if you want something new.  They're nice, you'll probably enjoy the food, but you just might be on the fence on returning.
author: A C.

description: I keep forgetting to write up this place.   It is fantastic from start to finish.   Happy hour prices are great.   All the dishes are fab.  You'd think the prices are high but the portions are huge (the tuna ceviche is tasty,  but calling it a tapas is misleading because you only need a few here. ..giant amount).  I'm eating a salad right now at lunch from there. ..the passion fruit dressing is insane.   A salad people.   A salad.
author: A A.

description: There aren't enough stars for this place. We'll definitely be coming back. Our waiter was great and super efficient. The Lomo Saltado was one of the best things I've ever had in my life. The ajo de pollo was good too. Even the chips and salsa were amazing. I don't understand the negative reviews. Maybe the food wasn't super Peruvian (I don't know), it did taste almost Asian, but it was amazing whatever it was. Clearly an amazing chef.  The only thing not stellar was that the tuna tartare was a bit sweet - not bad, but sweeter than expected.
author: Nadine G.

description: The dishes are a bit hit or miss in my opinion. The aji de gallina was delicious but had tiny to medium-sized pieces of bone scattered throughout.
author: Christopher B.

description: I definitely will return here, but mostly likely on  Mondays, all night happy hour.  The food was very good and tasty.   Cocktails were excellent!  Our Bartender was helpful and friendly.
author: Spoon P.

description: This restaurant has it ALL! Food! Atmosphere and Location!! BEST DATE Night place or FAMILY visiting from out of town (in my case). Everything on the menu was AMAZINGLY! Top choices though were the Seco de Cordeo. Lomo Saltado,,and the Scallops Carlitos!! UNBELIEVABLE!! HIGHLY HIGHLY RECOMMEND!! Actually, pretty much everything on the menu!
author: Yolie H.

description: This place has awesome food. I ordered the tuna ceviche, aji de gallina and churros. Out of this world.  I highly recommend this place.
author: Nishant S.

description: We want to mochica for dinner, great food. Authentic  Peruvian. I'm Peruvian  I know. Coming back for sure!!!!
author: Franco S.

description:
Came in on a Saturday night and were seated immediately. The restaurant was fairly empty and the table arrangement in the dining room felt a bit awkward. 

We ordered ceviche, lomo saltado, aji de gallina, and churros to top it off. The food was good, but nothing really stood out. It's a bit more expensive than a few of the other Peruvian options in the city and the taste doesn't justify the added cost. The churros were phenomenal, I'd go back just to get that. 

The service was fine, but I did have one big gripe. When we sat down we were offered sparkling or still water. We opted for the sparkling. When the bill came I noticed that we were charged $9 for a bottle of sparkling water. There was never any mention of a surcharge, which probably should have been divulged when it was offered. If it was a small upcharge I wouldn't sweat it, but I've never seen a bottle of water cost 9 dollars at a restaurant. It's a bit ridiculous 

It's worth trying this place once, but there was nothing that would make me want to come back for another try.
author: Jake B.

description:
I have been in this restaurant before in 2012 and the food was better. Maybe they have changed the cook/Chef.
The Pollo a la Brasa was very dried and no flavor at all. We had a tamal that was terrible with some kind of salsa/tomato on top and inside like a Mexican tamal. Cebiche was better than the other dishes.
I wish they would hire Peruvian cooks/chefs or people who have been trained in Peru.  We are in need and I hope o bring more Peruvian cooks to USA. I was born and raised in Peru. Some of these plates are not authentic. Is not the way it should taste.
author: The Bird W.

description:
Used to be better. Lomo used to be better, they used some odd tomato based sauce vs. soy sauce based. Kinda strange love lomo but this place kinda sucks for it now. Need to change back to what it used to be. I prob won't be back when my wife brings up this Place for dinner.

Also to note the table next to us also had a problem with the lomo as well. So it's just not me. Lamar is better and more consistent. 

The service was ok.
author: Mihaly P.

description: Had a really nice dinner here.  The tuna tartare and the paella were both great!  The service was excellent and I enjoyed the atmosphere.  This place is family friendly which is also another bonus.  I will definitely be returning here.
author: Alice A.

description: If you like ceviche, you absolutely have to try the Leche De Tigre.  The flavors are insane.  The cebiche de pescado is also incredibly good.  The beef heart is also really, really good.
author: Melanie S.

description: Great Peruvian food, although slightly overpriced. Cool ambiance with GF and vegetarian options. Service could be a little bit better but place is always packed so I can't blame them. Food is the highlight of the establishment, great flavors and high quality ingredients.
author: Charles W.

description:
I ordered tha calamari relleno and ceviche mixto.

The food is very refreshing and clean. Foods are not spicy but each dish is infused with a different flavor.
author: Lola A.

description: Officially my favorite restaurant of the moment.  Never had a bad meal yet.  The ceviche and the baby octopus were favorites.  Always great service.
author: Tony V.

description:
Must try, dispute of all the 2 or3 stars my experience was great.
Feb 14 came in at 6 pm was greated and seated right away . service was fast and food was delicious . Server named Baruch was helpful Will visit again.
author: Inder S.

description: I was excited to see they had Lomo Saltado on the menu and it was excellent. I substituted yucca fries for French fries. The two of us shared the tequenos appetizer (fried wontons with Oaxaca cheese and a powdered sugar dusting) and it was interesting and tasty. The panna cotta dessert with passion fruit purée was delicious. We didn't have alcohol but was still a bit pricey. I look forward to going back.
author: Sara M.

description:
First of all I have to say the staff was great. Edgar made our evening a real pleasure, a perfect balance of casual and formal. We would come back to Mochica just to have him serve again. 

We had the mushroom empanadas, the duck chicharrones, beef tongue and steak. The empanadas were our favorite.  The crust was light and flaky and filled with a tasty filling. We would order the duck chicharrones again. Juicy and full of flavor. The beef tongue was so delicate we could cut it with our fork. 

We tasted every pisco sour they had.  While they were all tasty most were too sweet to pair with dinner. The classic pisco sour was the best.  They carried En Cante Pisco which was a bonus.

Only draw backs were noise, we could hear all of the conversations of the people around us.
author: Ray M.

description: This is one of our go-to restaurants in potrero. Simply put, the aguadito soup is hands down the best soup I've ever had. Its great for warning up, defeating a hangover, or just generally making you feel great. The staff is inviting and the kitchen makes all of their items from scratch. That doesn't mean slow service though, as they practice proper mis en place.
author: Richard L.

description:
Mochica is one of my favorite restaurants to eat in San Francisco. We usually start the evening with a nice bottle of Malbec or a Chica Sour as we enjoy complimentarily Peruvian corn. We will then order a variety of dishes to share:

Cebiche Mixto (three types of cebiche and my favorite Mochica offering)
Beefheart Anticucho
Pulpito a la Parilla (my second favorite as it's paired with blue mashed potatoes)
Bolitas de Yucca
author: Linda P.

description:
Ambiance is nice. Service is ok. 

Food : Nope nope nope. Peruvian food is some of the most delicious cuisine on the planet. For whatever reason this place thought they could make it "modern." I'm a fan of modern food, but Peruvian food doesn't need it and this place doesn't know how to do it. For a modern take on Peruvian, go to La Mar on Embarcadero and pay through the nose for tiny (but delicious) portions and a view. Otherwise, if you know Peruvian food keep it down home the way Lomo Saltado is supposed to be and just stick to a more humble establishment like Mi Lindo Peru (recommended by native Peruvians)
author: Dani E.

description:
Brunch only review.

3 meals no booze.

Ceviche for 1 - eggs benedict for 1 and the Chicken chicharrones for the other. 
Ceviche was really pretty tasty as were the chicken chicarrones. The eggs benedict with pork belly was supposed to be the following: Two eggs, poached, Panorama English muffin, huancaina hollandaise with Pork Belly for $15.00. The English Muffin was some very small pieces of toasted baguette, the pork belly was very small pieces of fried / dried out bacon. I was envisioning some velvety pork belly chunks and the hollandaise sauce consisted of a few dots of sauce. Brunch only for 3 - no booze, 1 dessert and 1 cappuccino was over $70.00 with tip. We all left hungry. I wish them luck.
author: Cindy J.

description:
A-OK is a fair rating.  Overall, I liked the original location better.  

The physical restaurant is prettier and more comfortable.

It seemed like more staff than the original location which didn't correlate to better service though.  Lots of staff 'walking around' but somewhere in the Monday evening service our waiter disappeared.  We saw as we were walking out that she also had tables on the opposite end of the restaurant.  Not sure why restaurants do that.

The food was mediocre at best.  The original location must have had a different cook/chef.  Everything seemed to lack seasoning.  Adding a tad of salt and pepper (which is not on the table) to the paella brought it to life. 

Definitely not worth the price though.  With a handful of dishes and 2 alcoholic drinks, the cost (before tip) was $115.

You won't see me back here,  Too many better restaurants in SF to repeat expensive and mediocre.
author: Victor P.

description:
Came here because plow had a long wait and it was the only restaurant that had remotely close to a brunch menu at 10 am. And no waiting! 

No waiting for our table actually meant waiting over 45 minutes for our food to get there! There was really no one in there. I saw 1 other table and couple of guys at the bar. That's it so I'm not sure if they had a late start prepping the food but no one had informed us. We had a hungry toddler and it would have been nice to be warned. When the food finally came it was just barely mediocre. Had the open faced sandwich for myself and the bun was supposed to be toasted but it was cold. My boyfriend had their scramble which was okay. We also had 2 sides of bacon. When it came one plate of bacon was cold and the other one was super hot. The little appetizer they serve when we sat was good though but won't be coming back here again. Just didn't hit the spot
author: Ava L.

description: Delicious Peruvian cuisine! Recommend the Jalea, the Chaufa with seafood is amazing and the ceviche is perfection......a little on the pricey side so be ready to splurge a little. I give them a 3 because they were out of Chicha morada when I visited, which is a Peruvian staple so I was a little disappointed when I asked for a drink that had it as an ingredient.......The service was a little slow at first but the staff is really nice and friendly. Most of the drinks that are made with Pisco, we have not been disappointed with those.......I will be returning here for sure to give it another chance just hoping they won't be out of Chicha morada! And that the portions get a little bigger for the price.........
author: Veronica V.

description: Can't wait for them to open and go back.  They were so generous with their very specialty drinks.  The appetizers were so good, everything they served was with so much detail.  Excellent service.  Great neighborhood location.  Lots of parking spaces in the neighborhood.
author: Helen L.

description:
I took my family (group of 5) for my mother's birthday dinner. My family is Peruvian so I was hoping Mochica wouldn't disappoint. Wait staff was attentive and friendly. Decor was modern and chic but had a Peruvian twist. None of that kitschy decorations. Ordered some chilcanos (ginger ale and pisco) very tasty, strong and inexpensive

FOOD - 2 of us had the Aji de Gallina. That's a tricky dish to pull of and I have had some bad versions of it. This dish was tasty and well done. My aunt had the Pollo a la Brassa; it was a half chicken with choice of two sides and sauces. Delicious and great value for $15, perfect to split between to people. My brother had the Seco de res; I should have ordered that! It looked amazing. I had the pork belly chaufa, the waiter said it was his favorite. I like it and thought it was pretty good but everyone else's food was so good I was slightly disappointed, the pork belly could have been a bit crispier. Overall, very reasonably priced, delicious in a cute neighborhood. Will definitely return
author: Mario S.

description:
Mochica is off to a great start!  This location had moved from the previous location in Soma and now in Potrero Hill.  We happen to drop by on their soft opening on our evening run yesterday.  The restaurant host gave us a warm welcome and invited my girlfriend and I to try their food. Chicken Chicharones and Ceviche on purple yucca chips were the standouts.  It went down nicely with our Pisco sours sprinkled with cinnamon on top.  The service was attentive and friendly!  

Now that they are now conveniently located in the neighborhood, you will be seeing more of me!
author: SP S.

description: I'm glad I did find this place. First, the location in Potrero Hill is spectacular, and the restaurant itself gives you a great welcome and great vibe experience from the momento you walk in. I waited at the bar while our table was gettind ready, and the bartenders Renato and Yuri were amazing for the short time we were at the bar. Our server was very attentive and knowledgeable. White tempranillo!!! Amazing wine selection. And great food pairing. Ceviche chino peruviano, a must try. Pollo a la brasa heaven ok n your mouth. Yukka balls... Cocktails, try the forbidden pisco, and sexy smokey cocktail with mezcal and pineapple, well rounded in every single sip.
author: Armando M.

description:
Satisfying, meaning OK but not great. 
The Costillita de Chancho (pork ribs) tasted like ones I've had dozens of times, except here priced a little on the high side at $13. Fine, but at variance with the hip appearance of the restaurant.
The Camarones de Ajo (Mexican shrimp) was slightly better, due to a terrific sauce that came with. We asked for extra bread (charged $2 for) to mop this up. The shrimp themselves either weren't very well cooked or weren't very fresh, and tasted like the frozen variety at Trader Joe's. Dish could have been improved by free bread for the asking. 
The Chancho de Adobado (pork shoulder) was terrific, but again could have used more free bread. The pork was tender, and the dish nicely salty. 

I wanted to like the restaurant more. The food was okay, but over-priced for the result given. For what I've described above, and three beers, after tip, was approximately $90. Service was good, we got seated without a reservation on a Friday night without difficulty, which made us happy. A little annoying that the restaurant was so loud, which is perhaps not the restaurant's fault but as I said--annoying.

 I don't think I'll be going back.
author: Brian G.

description: We came to celebrate a special date with many friends and they kindly set up a table for all of us. Excellent food, good portions, great great service, smiles everywhere and very nice ambient!!
author: Juliana M.

description: It is the third time i come to the restaurant, but the first i seat at bar. I was impressed with the list of cocktails, for a Peruvian restaurant they seem to be serious about their bar Pisco program. Try Forbidden  Pisco cocktail , with Pisco apple infused, or the bloody rye (rye whiskey, blood orange, absinthe) super yummy, also the bartender is an extra star
author: Jilmer M.

description:
I was in town for a convention and wandered upon this restaurant near where I was staying.  WOW FANTASTIC! 

Probably one of the top 3 dining experiences over the past year.

Started with Cebiche, then the Ribs which were out of this world. Flavors really strong, complex and still comforting.  Finished with ground chicken meatballs.

A very nice Malbec accompanied my meal and then called it a night.

I would go back to this restaurant anytime I am in San Fran.

Waiter was excellent as well, very attentive and informative.  Seemed to love what he was doing and knew the food well.
author: Mike N.

description: This is a remarkable restaurant. They have looked after every detail. Not only is the ceviche outstanding but it has choclo that you can enjoy with a Cristal beer. The churros and the little cup of hot chocolate are a perfect closing.
author: Roberto C.

description: As a Peruvian guy (born and raised) that loves food, I can say that this is my favorite Peruvian restaurant. They have a great balance of traditional Peruvian dishes, their own dishes made of traditional Peruvian ingredients and awesome Pisco (Peruvian alcohol) cocktails. Even though the service didn't use to be the best, I noticed that they improved it quite a bit by giving you a good dinning experience and having smooth talker bartenders.
author: Carlos C.

description: Tourists to San Francisco, we visited Mochica on Saturday night. We ordered Pulpito a la Parilla, which was to die for and Beef Heart Anticuchos, which were delicious. The food was servered quickly, beautifully and in a friendly manner. A special shout out goes to the drinks, however. It is difficult to get a nice cocktail, they are frequently watery, lacking in flavor and alcohol. Not at Mochica! Pisco Sours, that Eduardo, their bartender served up, were bursting with flavor and had quite a kick!
author: Yury M.

description: My friend raved about the Paella. I enjoyed the roasted chicken and yucca fries. Good service and friendly neighborhood vibe.
author: Vicki L.

description: Great drinks and most of the staff is helpful. We were at the bar for drinks - there were 2 bartenders, found the second one bartender (who stayed till closing time) to be incredibly rude and unhelpful. The couple next to us even asked what we thought of the service because it was that bad. It's a real shame - would recommend this place if not for that experience.
author: Gautam G.

description:
Oh dear... I hate writing negative reviews like this, but I have to give my own personal opinion.

First, I want to state, "I love Peruvian food". But this restaurant is not even close to a Peruvian food experience !! I won't go into a detailed dissertation of what we had, but let me put it this way... It was an embarrassment to call this Peruvian food !!!! it was like expecting a great steak at McDonalds!!!
author: Mark S.

description:
I'll start off by saying that I had a fantastic experience working with the restaurant manager Victor, planning an event, as well as dining at the restaurant.

My fiancée and I are planning a lunch for our family following our wedding ceremony and without having been to the restaurant at all, made a reservation on OpenTable for 18 people! First off, very cool of them to let us do that. I followed up with a call to the restaurant just to confirm and eventually started working with Victor the restaurant manager, who invited us in for a tasting and tour.

We went last night and Victor sat down with us and went through how they could set up tables for us, went through pretty much the entire menu and how we could build any kind of meal we wanted for our lunch. A la carte, family style, formal coursed dining...whatever we wanted to do. Most other places we spoke with about hosting a group our size had a fixed menu with little to no options. Really great, personalized service here.

Now the food...we tried a lot of food. 

First they bring out a few purple potato chips which are great way to start the meal. Our first appetizers were Tequenos (fried cheese wonton) and Bolitas de Yucca (fried potato ball with ham and cheese). As much as I liked the Oaxaca cheese in the Tequenos, the Bolitas de Yucca are a more balanced dish. Both are very good. Followed up with beef heart and chicken anticuchos (grilled skewers). Beef heart is good, but may not be for everybody; the chicken, however, was phenomenal. Also the skewers are served with a grilled potato with huancaina sauce (similar to nacho cheese, except amazing), so good. I also tried the Cebiche Pescado and thought it was very good, although I would never claim to be a cebiche expert.

For main entrees we had the Seco de Res (short rib) which was okay, nothing particularly special, as well as the Pollo a la Brasa (rotisserie chicken) which was very well prepared. Thigh and legs were very moist; the breast dried out a little bit, but that's hard to avoid. Comes with chimichurri and aji Amarillo sauce to dip it in, which helps with the dryness of the breast, and also adds incredible flavor. I would say that even without the sauce, the chicken has great flavor. On the side, we had the Ensalada Nuovo Andina (salad with quinoa and beets) which was very good, as well as yucca fries which were delicious. We had a number of fried dishes (yucca balls, tequenos, yucca fries and churros) and none of them were oily in the least, which was impressive. 

And finally for dessert, we had mini alfajores and churros with dulce de leche and dipping hot chocolate. Alfajores were not too sweet, which some people might prefer, and the texture of the cookie was good. If you want something sweeter, the churros are probably the way to go.

Overall, a really incredible meal and experience. We look forward to going back to sample more of the menu and finalize our lunch menu. Thanks again to Victor and the staff!
author: Zachary S.

description:
I'm not typically a negative reviewer, in fact this may be my first one. To begin with proper direction: 
I came with two other people. It didn't take long to get seated, yay, but it took for EVER to get a drink and order. After the first drink, we had to waive the waitress for our next drink which came in two parts because she only took our friend's order and not ours. Mind you we drank them slowly. After that, our appetizer arrived and we had no cutlery or plates to share it because they didn't bother to set us up. Luckily the sweet buzzboy helped us. He set us up and we ate our appetizer. Again, it took forever for the food to get here and I mean FOREVER. Food got here, they FINALLY refilled our water and we started to eat. The food was too salty and they obviously had frozen potatoes instead of real potatoes. My boyfriend's food was bland. Bummer. The waitress came by only when she absolutely had to, the dinner was expensive for what it was and disappointing... It's a bummer this place sucks, I'd love to leave something positive but not even the wine was good. 

I hope they step up their game.
Sorry I had to leave this horrible review but it's such a bummer and I believed in you. :(
author: SIlver O.

description: Love this spot - some of the best Peruvian food around (and I've spent time checking out the Lima food scene...). A great addition to the neighborhood. All the dishes we've tried are very tasty and the service is way friendly. A fun place to go with friends and family.
author: Dan C.

description: Awssome neighborhood spot! Stopped by for the first time (as I work nearby) for a quick lunch and am in love! They just opened a few months ago and have a great team in place, intimate and lively decor/ambiance, and solid menu. I had the salmon special for lunch and sat at the bar. Took a peek at their happy hour and would love to go for that as well as to try out other delicious sounding items like their cebiche and lomo!
author: Cora M.

description: Awesome food! I like everything here. They also have Allset app that allows to get your food and table ready when you arrive. allsetnow.com
author: Stas M.

description: Excellent food!! As a peruvian myself I can say that this is the best peruvian place in town! The service was great and the drinks are THE BEST! Try the chica sour!
author: Ximena V.

description: Love the cocktails here. I am a beer person because I feel most cocktails are too sweet and not very original so I never order cocktails when I am out. However, Yuri makes some amazing drinks. All the names are ingredients are creative and have just the right amount of sweet-to-tart ratio. The piscos are great, but I'd recommend the Apaisonada, the Cebiche (a little spice), GreenGa, or the Sangre y arena if you want to try an original cocktail with some traditional Peruvian-inspired taste. The chips and the spicy dipping sauce that come with the drinks are the perfect combo (before of course you give in and order something from their menu).
author: Tatiana G.

description:
Great addition to the Hill!  Great lomo saltado, plantains, ceviche and all the other Peruvian favorites. The space is comfortable and welcoming, but what really sold me was the service.  The staff noticed that we didn't finish the tuna (we were too full, but it was good) and refused to charge us for it, even though we insisted we were happy to pay for it.  Wow, talk about dedication to your customers.  

I went back later the same week and had another great experience.  Two for two!
author: M D.

description:
I found about this place on Sosh, and I decided to give it a try. I made a reservation for four on a Friday night. I got there and was quickly greeted by three or four people immediately after walking in. I was seated right away, which is nice because I hate when restaurants won't let you sit until everyone is there.


We ordered a bunch of food, including the chicken skewers, pork belly, ceviche and empanadas. We loved everything. The food was amazing. We actually liked the pork belly so much that we decided to order a second one.

Overall, our service was almost perfect. Our waitress was super nice, friendly and attentive. The only reason I'm not giving it a perfect 5 stars is because the staff kept getting our order mixed up with other people's. They came around 3 or 4 times with food to give us that we didn't order. The first time it was funny but it started to get annoying after it happened more than once.

The atmosphere was nice. It's not the biggest restaurant, so if you don't like smaller spaces I wouldn't recommend it. Everything we had to eat, we loved. We asked the waitress for some recommendations and she was spot on. We even had dessert...the churros. And they were AMAZING! We will definitely be going back.
author: M H.

description: Wow!I think this is one of the best restraunts I've ever been to!The service was great,the food was DELICIOUS,(I had half a chicken,and the atmosphere was great! Plus the parking was really great and I had no trouble having a spot!I loved this place! 5 stars for you!!!
author: Kimbely B.

description: Ahhhhh, love this place. I had one of the best dishes of my life here -- their pork belly entree, OMG! Everything here is phenom - great staff, great food, great sangria! Def going back!
author: Christine J.

description: Very nice people, but the ceviches were too coarse, and the meat dishes do not hold a candle to the always excellent steak frites at chez Maman.  Perhaps a pisco sour at the bar is a good choice but there are so many other options from Mission to Dogpatch and in between.
author: Laurel B.

description: Brunch was fantastic. We got an empanada, the poached egg, and the omelet and all were tasty and tender.  Excellent flavors and the hot sauce (per my bf) was unique and delicious. We'll be back!!
author: Halley C.

description: Dined for lunch Sunday for the first time. Delicious!!!!  Wonderful service and amazing food. We loved the Cebiches, epanadas, roasted chicken and yummy drinks. Also saw lots of lovely brunch dishes on other tables. Absolutely will go back.
author: Susan T.

description: Came into the restaurant with a couple of friends, 10min before closing last Saturday, and we were surprised by the excellent service we were provided regardless of what time it was. The manager even came over to our table a couple of times to check on how everything was going. The food and drinks were amazing. I will definetly be back for more.
author: Pedro G.

description: Have been to Fresca, a good though noisyPeruvian restaurant, and to La Mar, a much-praised but in my view over-rated one---Mochica is the best one yet. Went for lunch with friends about a month ago, including one who has lived in Peru. We all agreed that the food was not only excellent, but also very attractively presented. The restaurant itself is charmingly decorated & I can imagine the bar being a very cosy, lively place come evening. Good, efficient service. Not pricey at all, considering the quality.
author: Helen P.

description: Best Pisco Sour in the Bay Area. The food is delicious and the service is excellent. This place is a must try, you won't be disappointed.
author: Nelson G.

description: The service was wonderful even though it took a while to get the food here. I got a seafood dish--cau cau, which was fantastic.
author: Pim H.

description: The food was okay, not great, and overpriced. The pisco sours were very good though. The service was excellent, especially considering that it was packed. Will I return? Maybe, maybe not.
author: Joan F.

description: One of my gf's friends said this place was great, so I looked at their menu on Yelp and got really excited about trying the beef tongue and their lamb shank. Unfortunately when we got there we came to find out that they don't have those items on the menu anymore. Strike one-not cool! I gave it the benefit of the doubt since our peer was hyping it up. For starters we had the beef hearts which were on skewers - they weren't bad 7-10 and then baby octopus which were alright - 6/10. Main dishes were paella - 7/10 - too saffron heavy and I had the pork shoulder -there were 2 pieces one of them was really dry and the other was better but still a little too well cooked. 6/10 My martinis (Chopin) were $15 a pop and the pisco sours which I heard were good were $12 each. The sides we ordered were not memorable and came after our dinner as the server didn't remember what we ordered - was slow service overall. 5/10 Definitely not impressed and will not be going back anytime soon!
author: Gibran P.

description: Had a way too poor quality steak for $28. A decent quality steak should be over $20 and a really good quality of steak should be over $35. Steak's sauce that they made was ok but the quality of the meat was horrible.
author: Alper K.

description:
Maybe it was a bad night, but this place was wholly unimpressive. First of all, Potrero Hill is not L.A. Let's just make that clear. 

Secondly, the food comes in bits and spurts, somewhat like the dripping of a leaky faucet. We received approximately 4-5 pieces of romaine lettuce with a singular unfortunate anchovy that was termed a "Caesar Salad," followed (approximately an hour later) by an elementary-school-lunch sized portion of pork shoulder that could have easily been mystery meat with barbecue sauce alongside a half-scoop of rice-a-roni. As our less-than-enthused server handed us the amuse bouche of an entree that cost $18, she gently reminded us that the kitchen was closed. 
AS IF we would stay there till next wednesday waiting pathetically for another bite of mediocre overpriced tv dinner.
author: Caitlin M.

description: As a peruvian I approve this place. The pisco sours are one of the best i've had. They also have really delicious and innovative cocktails with pisco (and other drinks) that you cannot find in other places. The service is excellent, they were really attentive and gave excellent recommendations in times when i went for happy hour and on a regular weekend nights. The ceviche and antichuchos are also amazing. I too love the character and atmosphere.
author: Bruno T.

description:
Peru has one of the best cuisines on the planet, and Mochica represents it well. First, because the service is helpful and friendly, and second because our meal here was memorable. We ordered quite a variety of things and loved every single dish. The stand outs for me were the stuffed avocado and the stuffed squid. 
They have a full bar too.
author: D Z.

description: Such a fantastic experience!  The food was so full of flavor.  We started with the mixed ceviche plate to share and I could have made that dinner, but I'm glad I didn't stop there.  The pork shoulder melted in my mouth with an amazing sauce.  We don't live in SF but next time we're in town, this place is a MUST GO!
author: Joanne H.

description: This place is fantastic. We went for brunch and absolutely everything was great. Service, coffee, drinks and food. Highly recommend.
author: John C.

description: This is a restaurant with an identity problem, it kinda of seems as if it wants to be a little neighborhood restaurant, but misses the mark for a destination. It's  pricy for a neighborhood place, and the service, while lovely for a fancier restaurant, is tends toward the stiff and formal. The wine list is long on bottles and high priced with very few by the glass options and pricy. I would appreciate more by the glass options for a more reasonable price than the more than 10 dollars a  glass. The food is dear and portions seem to lack generosity for shared plates. All shared played too expensive for the portion. Paella to share contained exactly one shrimp and  a couple of tiny pieces of fish with  the portion and presentation in a cold bowl small for the 20 dollar charge for instance. Will not be rushing back but the food was good,  the experience and pricing lacking in a few areas.
author: Anibel B.

description:
Unfortunately, below-average food in general-- many things I tried were bland or just didn't work well with the sauces (ceviche with a sweet sauce?). One of the ceviches was okay, the filling in the squid was decent (though the squid was a bit rubbery), but just not very interesting.

And it was ridiculously pricey for what it is.
author: Max D.

description:
the best! literally all the food on the menu is delicious!!
best restaurant in Potrero Hill!!

Ceviche Mixto was delicious with purple potato chips
Grilled Octopus dishes was my favorite!
author: Chantal E.

description: The manager called me after reading my review. He told me he had been out that day and acknowledged staffing issues occurring that particular day. He invited me back in on him and I appreciated his offer. A demanding schedule has not allowed me to head in yet but I plan to in the future. I had no complaints regarding the food.
author: Carla N.

description: Food is good, service, not so much. We went on Sunday night and the rester aunt was clearly understaffed. The manger was serving and clearing tables. Had to ask for the check and, although they brought us a desert menu, we never saw anyone to order from it. A little pricey but the food may be worth it. Not so much a neighborhood place, but more a special occasion place.
author: Mark C.

description: The food and drinks were great.  We will for sure be stopping by there again.  Nice bartenders!
author: Imela R.

description: Amazing food - so unusual and delicious. Well prepared, clean, stylish atmosphere. The thyme & honey cocktail was out of this world! Such a happy vibe - and wonderful service too. Can't wait to return!
author: Bea K.

description: Mochica was wonderful!  Not only was the service great, but the cocktails and food are delicious!  Definitely a great Happy Hour spot, I can't wait to go back!
author: Shannon C.

description: The food and service both need a good bit of work. The pisco sours were pre-blended; as a consequence, they made their way to us on the watery side. The chilcano was much better received. When the food arrived -- the papa a la huancaina was just strange: too saucy outside, too dry inside. I turned to my companion and asked him if he found the ceviche de pescado, or was it just me. Nope. It was bland -- not because of a lack of ingredients, but more because the fish was tasteless (?!?) and the marinade was without any punch. And three small dishes, two drinks each taking us over $100 made neither of particularly inclined to return... certainly not until the food quality merits such a price tag.
author: Vincent R.

description: The food is really great, but sometimes the services can take a minute. As a Peruvian, this place reminds me of home and I'm always happy to be here. Definitely come here.
author: Elizabeth B.

description: Mochica is a hidden gem in Potrero Hill.  The food is flavorful and fresh tasting. I enjoyed this delicious avocado appetizer and the chicken chicharrones. The staff is friendly and attentive. It has a nice ambiance. But the best part of Mochica is the Peruvian drinks. I am a huge fan of pisco sours and this was one of the best I've had. I also recommend the pisco punch. They're the perfect combination of sweet, fruity, and sour. You can ask the bartender, Yuri, for recommendations. He knows his stuff. I'll definitely be back to Mochica!
author: Kristin S.

description: I like the ambience and wine list. The food is really delicious and they have a lot to choose from.
author: Nadia M.

description: Seriously good. Ceviche pescado was amazing. The cancha was great, as was the lava cake.
author: Milo T.

description: Great ceviche. No wait. Nice beets. The purple mashed potatoes with the pork shoulders were divine. Didn't try the pisco sours but they looked legit.  Closer to 4 than 5 stars but this is no 3 star spot.
author: Armen Z.

description: D-e-l-i-c-I-o-u-s!! You MUST try the salmon sandwich.  It isn't one of the usual suspects on a Peruvian menu (at least in my own experience)...just do yourself a favor and order it, though!
author: Poppy B.

description: To start, the cocktails featured some interesting combinations;  honey and thyme, jalapeño martini, cava sangria.  I wish my pisco lime concoction had more ginger beer than citrus, which made it watered down.  As for the food, dishes slightly larger than tapas-sized portions, and easy to share.  The ceviche, chiccarones, paella all tasty.  My coffee was weak but they gladly took it back for a stronger cup.  Definite highlight were the churros with a melty caramel inside.  Didn't even need the cup of hot chocolate it was served with.  All in all a fun place to try new twists on familiar food.  I'd return for the sangria, ceviche and churros.
author: Kristin U.

description:
We arrived at 1:30pm on a Sunday for brunch, and were seated immediately.

Food:

Cebiche Mixto - A basic pricey ($16) ceviche. Fresca in Noe/West Portal beats it in terms of flavor and freshness

Palta Rellena - A half avocado topped with beets, small strips of fried chicken and mayo. It looks interesting but like the ceviche, it did not have much flavor

Lomo Saltado - Basically stir fried beef with soy sauce, green onion, tomatoes, onions and rice. The seasoning was very basic, a little too bland for my tastes. Also price ($19).

Sangria - Too sweet, though it had lots of different kinds of fresh fruit (strawberry, blueberry, apple and orange).

Service:

Very friendly but they made several mistake with our order.  We did not order the Lomo Saltado, they packed up one of the dishes instead of serving it as requested and the total on the check was wrong, though they corrected it before we were charged.
author: Tom M.

description: The halibut ceviche had just the right amount of spice and zest; excellent yucca fries came with a delightful cheese sauce; crunchy caramel churros for dessert!
author: Philip S.

description: I came in to Mochica Saturday night and this place was packed. I told the hostess I needed a table for two, but didn't have a reservation. She told me to wait a minute and just like that she was able to get a table ready for me, I couldn't believe I was able to get a seat so quickly. I ordered the Seco and my date ordered the Aji de Gallino. The waiter told us those were the two best dishes on the menu and he was right. The food came quickly and vanished from our plates just as fast. I will be back.
author: Robert P.

description: One of my favorite places in the city!  Definitely not cheap, but the food is amazing.  The new location is great - much nicer neighborhood than before.
author: Max C.

description: Friendly bartender, thanks Yuri (?) for the drink and food suggestions. Tasty dish, I went by Yuri's recommendation for the chicken dish.
author: Ercenk K.

description:
Before I start I'd like to make a point of the fact that I had a $100 gift card for Mochica, and had no previous knowledge of the restaurant until I received this gift card for xmas.
Onto the review..

Ambiance is nice. Modern but not too pretentious, which is a pleasant surprise in this part of town. I friggin' LOVED the pork belly skewers. Probably some of the best pork belly I have had, ever. Churros, aahhh mouthgasm.

As for the service... like I said, I had a gift card. At no point during my dining experience was I made to feel less important due to the gift card. I find at some restaurants waiters will not be that attentive to Groupon/other gift card kinda situations. Our waiter was great and helpful in selecting menu items and wine pairings.

I will be back when my wallet allows (or when i receive another gift card, haha). Lovely place!
author: Ada G.

description: This place really isn't that good!! Crazy expensive for such bland food!!! I'm a big Peruvian Food person and this place has to be one of the worst Peruvian place ever!!! Lack seasoning! Food is just very bland!!! Their ceviche are not that good!!! Their scallops are not that good!! $14 for a pico sour? Really??? Come on!!! It's really isn't that good!!! Plus their sangria is way too sweet!!! Crazy expensive for such a bland place!!! I will never come back and will take my $$$ elsewhere with better food!!! Tastier food!!! Thank you!!!
author: Howard J.

description: I went the other day to this restaurant, because a friend recommended me. But it was unfortunately a bad experience, not because of the food, because it was delicious...it was because the prices are way to expensive. $12 for anticuchos, and they just give you one stick?...really??...in others peruvians restaurants they always give you two sticks. $14 for a ceviche...and it comes just 5 pieces???....this will be my first and last time to be in this restaurant...totally disappointed..
author: Violeta S.

description: Very disappointed in this new Potrero Hill Restaurant. Over priced both at the bar and at the table. Gin martini - somewhat skimpy - $12.00. Pisco Sour, $14.00 (their online bar menu shows $10.00)  An extensive wine list far more than needed.The pork shoulder, $19,00, was a small piece of bone with a few scraps of meat and fat - not too bad a sauce. The fried mixed seafood was a small/medium portion which would have made a good small plate or appetizer, but was over-cooked and very dry. It had two very bland unidentifiable sauces with it. Didn't bother with dessert. Why they had the tired old 'chocolate molten lava cake' on the dessert menu I have no idea - nothing at all to do with Peruvian food.
author: Ron M.

description: Mochica has lost its magic. Fans of the Harrison location will be crestfallen after seeing the diminished portion size, high prices, and most importantly, the mediocre quality of the food, at this new spot. Gone are the chickpea appetizers compliments of the house. The chicken stew (aji de gallina) was somehow stringy and dry. All other dishes were fine, but not worth the drive. Presentation was nice if you care about these things, and the churros filled with  dulce de leche were downright addictive. Still, for $150 for three, this first visit will likely be my last.
author: Jessica D.

description: Loved the Ceviche, very fresh and tasty! The Pescado a lo Macho was great too. Will be back!
author: Mary R.

description:
Went to Mochica for Father's day yesterday with the family. After reading some of the mixed reviews on Yelp, we were preparing for perhaps some slow service. However, it wasn't very busy when we went and service was great. Everyone loved the food! In particular, the beef heart skewer and this potato dish (don't remember the name of) were big hits with our party. The potato dish was like a fried/battered potato which was stuffed meat and cheese and was part of the Father's Day Special. It also came with a Pisco Sour because of Father's Day, which was also delicious. 
As a vegan, I did not partake in the beef heart and potato dish however the beet salad (ordered without goat cheese) and mushroom sandwich I had were very good. The sandwich was simple but very delicious. The only one complaint our party had was that the ceviche dish they ordered was lacking in flavor compared to all the other dishes.
The Churros were very good for dessert - they were filled with caramel and my family loved it. I think we all agree we would definitely be back to try other dishes!
author: Jogreet C.

description: Went with a friend for dinner on a Friday night and sat at the bar. The bartender was friendly,  super helpful, and attentive to us. The cocktail menu was quiet impressive - great variety and some interesting options. Bartender made some recommendations and even provided some free samples. We enjoyed several tasty and unique cocktails. Food selection was an interesting spin on traditional Peruvian food. We ordered several small plates to share and I also got a pulled pork sandwich - it was all very delicious! I was impressed with how fast the food came out relative to how busy it seemed. Looking forward to coming back soon and will plan to sit at the bar again to hang with the cool bartenders :)
author: Andrew R.

description: Somewhere between 2-3 stars is the ideal rating for Mochica. There's nothing really great about this place, the food is par, but not the quality I was expecting for the prices. We were a party of 9, so we tried and shared just about everything. For starters, the tuna ceviche is a definite winner. The flavor of the pomegranate seeds and the tuna is a solid combination. Don't get the ceviche sampler though, as it is minimalistic at best, served in the tiniest of dishes and is probably good for only 2-3 people. All meat dishes tended to border on the salty side, but the beef was far more flavorful then the chicken dishes. The paella, we ordered both the regular tomato base as well as the squid ink, was lacking in seafood. How can serve this dish without prawns?!? We only got 1 prawn in 3 paella dishes... definitely unacceptable. And the black paella (squid ink) was way too heavy on the ink. Our drinks were slow too; we received our food before we had enough glasses of water on the table for everyone, and the cocktails were inconsistent in their concoction. Yet there only appeared to be one bar tender... The service was just okay, kind of unacceptably slow for the small space. Ending on a few good notes - the plate presentations, the coffee, the ambience, the decor.
author: T P.

description: I went to Mochica for brunch with a few friends and we sat at the bar. The bartender was really nice and prepared amazing drinks for us. I was surprised that their pan con chicharron was so authentic. As a Peruvian, myself, I find it hard to get the authentic Peruvian flavor in gourmet restaurants, but I loved everything we order. The ambiance was great and the people that worked there too. I will definitely come back to this place. I loved it!
author: Jimena B.

description: Was itching to go here since it opened - it looks very attractive from outside. The service was above average - the waitress was very helpful, friendly and attentive. The restaurant itself seems a little confused about its identity- caught between being a white tablecloth dinner spot and a hip flexible cocktail bar. Regardless, we were there for the food, and tried a couple ceviches and an empanada. The halibut ceviche was very good, although the pieces of fish were a little too large. It was quite spicy though, so watch out! The empanada was a highlight - it was fresh, rich and very tasty. The prices were a little high, but overall well worth a try. The restaurant adds variety to the Potrero fair and thus probably has staying power, but I have to say I've had better Peruvian food in the Mission.
author: Nikhil V.

description: I tried the food here and every single dish was awesome!!! I love their food, the drinks  was pretty good. The service was spectacular!! I would come back definitely! Overall, I really love this place :)
author: karla g.

description: My husband and I just moved to Potrero Hill and walked into this place for lunch. The food was amazing, with very interesting flavor combinations. Our server was also very friendly and helpful. We will definitely be back.
author: Berkeley A.

description: The first thing I noticed about Mochica was the small vibrant space.  For lack of a better word, the fungi shui really impressed me.  As you enter, you are greeted with the full bar and a view of the kitchen, where you can see all the food being prepared.  Most importantly, the staff present themselves in a sincere and friendly manner, but not that over the top cheesy type of service that has become common in the restaurant industry.  Smiles are genuine here.  The bartender, Flaco, is a fountain of knowledge and answered all my questions amicably while steadfastly attending to his duties.  He was a real treat to watch while we waited for our food.  The food was incredible, which is always the most important part.  Plates are prepared with care and come out as near works of art.  I had the beef hearts, along with the pulpos (octopus), ceviche and yucca balls.  For a drink, Flaco made me the best pisco sour I have ever had. Admittedly, I have not had that many, but still.  Everything was truly delicious, and I left Mochica fully satisfied.  You won't regret having a meal here.
author: Galen m.

description: My boyfriend and I went here for valentines day 2015 and I have to say from the time we sat down, we waited 20 min till someone came up to us and asked us what we wanted to drink. As we were waiting everyone kept getting the wrong dish. The waiters didn't even know which food orders went to what table. The couple next to us were eating their dinner when their dessert was brought out too early and the waiter asked if they wanted it now but they were like no we got our dinner.  The cebiche was way to acidic and my boyfriend ordered pork and was told it came with mash potatoes and it wasn't mashed potatoes but some cabbage salad. I couldn't wait for desert bc I got the churros and I bit into churro batter. It Was so bad it tasted like oil. The thing that did it for both of us was we ended up paying 160 including tip and not once did anyone ask how dinner was or even checked up on us. Customer service was not good. Not so happy Valentines dinner.
author: karina l.
